editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Female Vertuoſo's. A COMEDY: As it is Acted at the QUEEN's THEATRE, By Their Majeſties Servants. Written by Mr. THOMAS WRIGHT.

q.l: Oh, what a Midnight Curſe has he, whoſe Side
Is peſter'd with a Mood and Figure Bride!
Let mine, ye Gods! if ſuch muſt be my Fate,
No Logick learn, nor Hiſtory tranſlate,
But rather be a quiet, humble Fool;
I hate a Wife to whom I go to School.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by J. Wilde, for R. Vincent, in Cliffords-Inn-lane, Fleet-ſtreet, 1693.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, CHARLES, EARL of WINCHELSEA, &c.
div.p: WERE we to judge of Men by the Dedications of this Age, we ſhould have now as many Hero's as ever fought for the Conqueſt of Troy and Carthage, as many Politicians as ever ſate in the Senate of Rome, and as many true Wits as ever flouriſh'd in the Times of Auguſtus: But ſuch is the fulſome and laviſh Flattery of our mercenary Writers, that it is almoſt become a Reproach to a Patron to be Commended; for while their common Topicks of Praiſe, applied right or wrong, make all alike, What Rule can we go by, to make a difference between a Coxcomb and a Man of Merit?

Having therefore ſo far ſtudied your Lordſhip, as to be ſatisfied, That you hate Commendation as much as you deſerve it; I ſhall forbear impoſing upon your Patience and Modeſty with a large and methodical Account of your own Vertues,
I leave to the World the Pleaſure to find 'em out; they are too many, to be concealed long; and too great, not to be admir'd as ſoon as known.

And without the Ceremony of a tedious Apology, I crave Your Lordſhip's Patronage for my FEMALE VERTUOSO's; the Deſign of which, as it was drawn ſome Years ago from the great Original of French Comedy, by an Ingenious Friend of mine, who bears now too ſerious a Character in the World, not to reckon ſuch a Trifle among his Delicta Juventutis, was laſt Winter, by my Importunities, extorted from him.

I ſhall not tire your Lordſhip with an Account of ſome frivolous Objections rais'd againſt this Firſt Eſſay of mine, by the factious Demi-Wits of the Town, who judge of a PLAY, not by the ſtanding Rules of Art, they never underſtood, but by the narrow Fancy, or mere Caprice, of ſome Conceited Fops their devout Ignorance adores, as Oracles of Sence and Ingenuity.

I ſhall only take notice to Your Lordſhip, That the nice and more judicious ſort of Criticks, whoſe Approbation only a Writer ſhould value, have obſerv'd, That my Vertuoſo's ſtretch in their Projects beyond the Limits of Nature and Reaſon; I do here, with the Candour of an Author not yet hard'ned in the vicious habit of Scribling, freely own it appear'd ſo to me, at firſt; but having, beſides ſome modern Poets, Ariſtophanes for a Pattern, I thought that what diverted the Ancients, might meet with ſome Indulgence from our Engliſh Audience. I am ſure, the Athenians could laugh to ſee no leſs a Man than Socrates expos'd upon their Stage, See the Clouds, Act. 2. Scene 2. for contriving a ridiculous way to meaſure the Jump of a Flea; but we are grown Serious, and cannot reliſh Fooleries: I ſubmit, only deſiring my Judges
to remember that a Poet may challenge it, not only as his Excuſe, but his Privilege, to carry ſometimes a Jeſt beyond the Bounds:

q.l: Dixero quid, ſi forte Jocoſius, hoc mihi Juris cum venia dabis.

closer.signed: I am, MY LORD, Your Lordſhip's Moſt Humble and moſt Devoted Servant, THO. WRIGHT.

div.head: PROLOGUE, Written by Mr. Doggett, and ſpoken by him.
div.l: ENrag'd to find you never do come near
The Theatre, but when New Plays are here;
I'm come to tell you with a ſerious Face,
Loathing of Wit do's ſhew a want of Grace.
The Time has been, when Sence has ſo prevail'd,
That of full Houſes we have never fail'd,
The Boxes ſtill with Beauties fill'd; the Pit
Was crouded every day with Men of Wit;
The Galleries ſerv'd for poor unthinking Citt.
Side-Boroughs ſtow'd Masks, and keeping Cullies;
And the Stage kept free from Beaux and Bullies:
There was ſome other Vermine up and down,
But they for fear of loſing Half a Crown,
Prepare for flight, like Owls at Evening Dawn,
And take to Wing before the Curtain's drawn;
Leaves us here to talk to empty Benches;
You to Whores, and Fools to Orange-Wenches.
This makes me ſpeak, theſe Grievances o'th'Age,
The Poet's Bane, and Ruine of the Stage,
The Fatal Cauſe that makes me look ſo thin;
'T has left me nothing on my Bones but Skin:
My Legs with Pain my Body long has carry'd,
I'm grown ſo weak—ſome cry—Look!—he's marry'd;
As if there was no other Plague, but Wife,
To make a Man a weary of his Life:
We have a greater Curſe to pull us down,
In being forc'd to pleaſe a barbarous Town;
Who damn all Wit, but what they call their own.

row.cell: Sir Maurice Meanwell, An honeſt rich Citizen.
Sir Timothy Witleſs, A Country Gentleman.
Sir Maggot Jingle, A Paraſitical Knight, pretending to Poetry.
Clerimont, A Gentleman of the Town, in love with Mariana.
Lady Meanwell, An imperious Wife; great Pretender to Wit.
Lovewitt, Lady Meanwell's Daughter by a former Husband; an Admirer of Platonick Love, yet in Love with Clerimont.
Mariana, Sir Maurice's Daughter by a former Wife.
Catchat, Lady Meanwell's Siſter, a ſtale Virgin, who fancies every Man is in Love with her.

sp.speaker: Lovewitt.
sp.p: LOok you, Siſter, if you have a Mind we ſhould live civilly together, pray not a word more of that monſtrous filthy thing Marriage, fough!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not of Marriage, Siſter? you Jeſt ſure.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh for Shame forbear! Can Fleſh and Blood hear the Word, and keep within Bounds? The very ſound of it leaves ſuch an impreſſion of filthineſs and obſcenity in the Mind, that I have need of all my Morals to ſilence Nature in me: Bleſs me! What refin'd Soul can bear the impure Conſequences of ſo nauſeous a Thing?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Without much Conjuring; when I reflect on Marriage, all I can ſee in it, is a dear Husband that will love me, pretty Children that will play about me, and a Houſe of my own to manage: and, for my part, I cannot perceive what there is in any of theſe Things offends Decency, or ſhocks good Manners.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Jeſu! That One born with a Spirit, capable of ſublime and lofty Things, ſhould fooliſhly limit her ſelf to the enjoyment of ſo mean, and ſo deſpicable a Creature as Man!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Believe me, Siſter, 'tis not prudence in frail Woman to Huff and Hector; for either ſhe yields in time; and then how inſultingly does a Man triumph o'er her conquer'd Pride? Or if, to the laſt, ſhe can boaſt of the venerable Title of Virgin, Does not the ſatirical World ridicule her Wiſdom, and mock her Singularity? Till almoſt choakt with Vapours, and devour'd with Spleen, ſhe makes in Policy a poor ſhift to rail at Men that ſcorn
her; and grudging to the Young the Joys ſhe has out-lived, ſhe pines away with Envy, and dies a fretting Martyr for a reproachful Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Poor Soul! how deeply is the Spirit in you immerſed in the foul Abyſs of your Senſes. Go on pretty Miſs, pleaſe your ſelf with fond and airy Notions. But know this, That if there be Fancy in your Choice, there is Judgment in mine. To Philoſophy, and not to Man, do I give the Empire of my ſelf; I ſcorn to yield to common Laws, and to make that Reaſon a Slave to Mankind, which kind Heav'n imparted free to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is Heroick indeed: but, pray good Siſter, with all your Wit, can you anſwer me this Queſtion? What ſort of Figure had you made in the World, had your wiſe Progenitours always been wrapt up in lofty Speculations, or muſing upon muſty Books; had they never condeſcended to talk familiar Things, and now and then diſcourſed plain Nature together? Well, ſince I cannot be a Wit my ſelf, I'll try to bring Wits, and to ſtock the World with little Doctors, that ſhall propagate Learning to all Generations.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I pity you, poor Siſter: But pray, ſince you are ſo very fond of that Ceremonious Piece of Ruine, let's hear at leaſt, who is the worthy Object of your Inclinations,—I hope, not Clerimont?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why not Clerimont, pray? Does he want Merit? Is his Eſtate ſo mean? or, Is there any Thing in his Perſon ſhould make one bluſh at the Choice?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I do not ſay there is; but you cannot be ignorant that he is mine already by right of Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord, Siſter, muſt then ſo vaſt, and ſo ſublime a Genius as yours, limit it ſelf to the Enjoyment of ſo mean a Creature as Man!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Reaſon, which is my Guide, and not my Tyrant, do's not diſapprove of the Courtſhip of a Man of Vertue; tho' I may hate him for a Husband, yet he may pleaſe me well enough, under the Title of an Admirer.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Paſſionate Speeches, Fond Addreſſes, Platonick Gallantry, and ſuch Toys, may feed up the Vanity of a Woman: But, Siſter, Are you ſure Love has nothing more to deſire?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thanks to my Wit, I can anſwer for One; and I ſhould make a ſad Example of the daring Mortal, that ſhould attempt to rifle the precious Magazine of my Chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But after all, What Aſſurance have you, that Clerimont is yours?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Surely, after a Thouſand Declarations of his Love, I think, Siſter, I may rely upon his Sincerity in ſpite of Rivals.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do not love to boaſt; but if you have a mind to try it, here comes one ſhall decide the Quarrel. Come on Clerimont, and without any Fear, or Partiality, diſcloſe your Heart. My Siſter challenges your Love, and I flatter my ſelf I have a right to it; let's ſee in whoſe Favour you'll declare your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am not ſo fond, Siſter, of a publick Declaration, as to put any Man I value, to the hard Extremity, either of Diſſembling, or Diſobliging: the One is as unworthy of a Man of Honour, as the other is againſt the Rules of fine Breeding.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: No, Madam; my Heart, incapable of Diſſembling, does not ſcruple to own an Engagement which is the Pride and Happineſs of my Life: Fair Mariana's Charms are ſuch as will eaſily juſtifie the greateſt Paſſion in the World.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But can thoſe mighty Charms, Sir, be a good Excuſe for Baſeneſs and Infidelity?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Do me more Juſtice, Madam; and impute to your ſelf the blame of my Inconſtancy: 'Tis that ſtiff and imperious Carriage of yours, that cold Indifferency you affected upon all Occaſions, and your high boaſting of the tyrannical Empire you exercis'd over me, have at laſt open'd my Eyes, and reſtor'd me to the Uſe of my Reaſon; and can you now complain, or—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I Complain? No Sir, you miſtake me; my Reſentment would make you proud, and fancy that your Heart was a Conqueſt worth my keeping.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now, Siſter, here's a Scope for your Philoſophy with a vengeance: ſumm up all your Morals to your Aſſiſtance; let's ſee if you can look upon a happy Rival with a Stoical and Undaunted Mind.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You triumph, Siſter, in your pretty Looks, and pleaſing Smiles, and think of Inſulting, perhaps too ſoon; feed your eaſie, deluded Soul, with empty Dreams of Pleaſure: Your Happineſs is not ſo great, as to deſerve my Envy—
—Nor perhaps ſo certain yet, as not to leave me ſome Proſpect of a Change.
sp.stage: [Aſide, and as ſhe is going off.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: However ſhe may endeavour to diſguiſe it, I am ſatisfy'd, ſhe is not a little offended at the Sincerity of my Declaration.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But I am pleas'd with it; and without the laborious Task of two years Love you have beſtow'd on her in vain, I give you leave to think me not Ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Still as you ſpeak, my Love diſcerns freſh Wonders; and to that free and generous Temper, ſo oppoſite to the little Artifices and Diſſimulation of your Sex, do I reſign all the Liberty your other Charms have left me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Miſtake me not, Clerimont; I ſet as high a Value upon the Modeſty of our Sex, as the beſt Moraliſts of 'em all; but yet I ſee no reaſon why we ſhould keep a Lover at ſuch a diſtance, when we are once ſatisfy'd of his Worth and Sincerity; ſince all the Incenſe after that exacted, ſerves only to gratifie the two great Idols of our Souls, Pride and Vanity, and gives no real Satisfaction either to Reaſon or Reputation.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Nay, proves often a piece of Policy very fatal to the Proud and Scornful of your Sex; for their Vanity forcing thus a pining Lover to ſpend his whole Stock of Love in Courtſhip, the Conſequence of it, is, That he has none left for Marriage.
sp.stage: Enter Lucy to Clerimont and Mariana.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I am quite out of breath!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's the matter now, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: The Matter? only Treaſon, High-Treaſon plotting againſt you two within.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I dare lay a Wager, your Siſter's Jealouſie has been at work.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: 'Tis e'en ſo; I never ſaw her Philoſophy ſo ruffl'd before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But what was the Reſult of it, Lucy? How did her Wiſe, her Witty Mother take it?

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: You know her Way; ſhe has always more Sentences in her Mouth than Teeth.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But ſtill let's hear a little.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: With a furious train of her bombaſt Expreſſions, and a flood of Latin, which, for ought I know, was all Swearing or Conjuring, ſhe did juſt now, in her Tone of Authority, pronounce, That Mariana, the Undutiful Mariana, ſhould have no other Husband but Mr. Timothy Witleſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Don't you tremble, Clerimont, at the Name of your Rival?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: No Rival, Madam, can ſeem dangerous to me, after your laſt Aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: No; on my Conſcience, you need not fear him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But how came you to know that Property, Mrs. Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: I have ſeen the Coxcomb at Cambridge: he was noted there for a mighty Boaſter of pretended Favours; and one could hardly name a Woman to him, but he had had the luck to lie with.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: A Scholar, on my Word.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Nay, he courted me once moſt fiercely; but I dreading Matrimony then, a little more than I do now, ſent him packing to his Grammar: Upon this, what does my mere Scholar do, Sir, to be revenged of me, but uſe me juſt as he do's his Books; for as he quotes every day Paſſages out of 'em, which he never read, ſo he boaſts of Favours of mine he never enjoy'd: ne'er truſt me, if I have not a month's Longing, to ſerve him a Trick for his Impudence.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: We'll joyn with you, Mrs. Lucy, I promiſe you: But firſt, Is the Man Eaſie? May we venture to play upon him?

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: The Man, Sir, is an exact Tool for our purpoſe; a good harmleſs Booby; ſo very honeſt, that as he carry'd no Wit to Cambridge, ſo he has the Conſcience to bring none from thence: a dull, lumpiſh, low-ſpirited Ninny, who is contented to be a Fool by Nature, and wants the Skill of our modiſh Sparks to make himſelf a Fool by Art.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: However, he muſt be removed; for in Matters of Love, a Fool is as troubleſome, as a Witty Man is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: I'll be content to die a Virgin, if I do not accompliſh it for you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Look to your ſelf, pretty Mrs. Lucy: You could not have bound your ſelf by a greater Curſe.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Then judge your ſelves:—My Brother Trap, who waits on him at Cambridge, in the manifold Qualities of Gentleman, Foot-man, and Valet de Chambre, ſent me word laſt Week, That his worthy Maſter was ſoon to ſet out for his Matrimonial Expedition:—He is famous for merry Tricks and Frollicks; and I dare anſwer for his Zeal, or be bound Body for Body, that he'll be true to the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I deſire no better Security.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This falls out as luckily as we could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: I'm inform'd that he is expected to day; I'll ſend for him, as ſoon as I hear he is come to Town, to Conſult with him, and ſet his Wits at work.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then let's ev'ry one to our Tasks immediately: Clerimont, my Uncle Meanwell is your Friend; you may try his Intereſt for my Father's Conſent.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Truſt, Madam, to my Love for obeying a Command, on which all my Happineſs depends; I'll about it preſently, only give me leave to wait on you within.

div.head: Scene Changes. The Street.
div.stage: [Enter Witleſs, ſhaking the flaps of his Coat, and making Faces.—With him Three Pick-pockets, and Trap with a Portmantua upon his Shoulders; Witleſs ſtanding between two of the Pick-pockets, while the third is amuſing Trap at one corner of the Stage.]

sp.speaker: Witleſs,
sp.p: Pox o' the Milk-woman, and my unlucky ſtumbling on her: ſhe was not Pretty neither: Fough! how ſhe has daub'd me! By the Univerſity, my Cloaths have dropt as much of her Stuff, as would ſuckle ten Pariſh-Baſtards.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Pick-pocket,
sp.p: How the buiſie, noiſie Rabble began preſently to ſwarm about you! 'Twas a great mercy, Sir, we came to your Reſcue, they would have pull'd you a' pieces elſe; for that untractable Crew, ſet up of late for Arbitrary Avengers of Wrongs, and like greedy Birds of Prey, are always flying to Miſchief.

sp.speaker: 2d. Pick-p.
sp.p: I was almoſt in a Fury, to ſee a Perſon of Quality ſo abus'd.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Quality! Ay, that I am; and for my Honour let it be ſpoken, the very Firſt that ever was of my Family.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Pick-p.
sp.p: May I crave your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: My Name, Sir?—My Father is a Knight, and I wou'd have the raſcally Mobb to know, that he'll talk Aſtrology with 'em for their Ears: By the Univerſity, I'll ſend a Challenge to the Vermin, and try how much of the Gentleman they have in their Doublets.

sp.speaker: 2d. Pick-p.
sp.p: Challenge the Mobb? You Jeſt ſure: The Mobb never fight; they only butcher, or knock one down, without either Method of Fencing, or Rules of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: 3d. Pick-p. to Trap.
sp.p: I had an itching Mind to have ſent half a dozen of thoſe Sons of Whores to their pocky Mothers, to make black Bacon of 'em.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Faith, I hate Blood-ſhed, and never was fond of Valour; I had rather live Three Days in this pretty ſinning World, than a Thouſand in Hiſtory.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Pick-p.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you come, Sir, to make the Town happy with your Company, for ſome time.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Truly, Gentlemen, my Buſineſs in Town, is the Buſineſs of any place I live in; Love-Intrigues; nothing elſe: I have of late ſo liberally Cuckolded the whole Pody-Politick of Cambridge, Mayor, Aldermen, &c. that I am forced to come up for the reliſh of Variety.

sp.speaker: 2d. Pick-p.
sp.p: London is a large Field for Love; you have been here, I don't queſtion, Sir: Pray, how do you like the City?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: The City, Sir? Faith, I think the City is well enough; but pox on't, there are ſo many Buildings in it, they hinder one from ſeeing it; wou'd they were pull'd down, we might then have a full Proſpect of it.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Pick-p.
sp.p: I ſee, Sir, ſo honeſt a Look in your Face, that with an humble Apology for my Freedom, I muſt give you a ſeaſonable Caution, and that is, To take heed what Company you keep in Town; and have a vigilant Eye upon any body that comes near you; for this great City was never ſo peſter'd with Pick-pockets, and buſie Rogues, as it is now.
sp.stage: [All this while the 2d. Pick-pockets is ſtealing Witleſs's Sword, and rifling his Pockets on one ſide.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Oh, the Villains, let me alone with them; I'll be cunning enough for 'em, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: 2d. Pick-p.
sp.p: But, Sir, what argues Impudence beyond Example? The officious Cheats will intrude themſelves into your Company, upon the ſpecious pretence of Civility: They'll make very free and extravagant Offers to you: But, Oh, the wicked Age we live in! while one of 'em is thus amuſing you with ſome impertinent Story, the other is very buſie in rifling your Pockets.
sp.stage: [All this while the firſt Pick-pocket is rifling Witleſs his other Pockets of a Pack of Cards, a Table-Book, Papers, &c

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Odd'zookers! give me but a Liſt of the Rogues; my Father is a Juſtice, and I'll ſee 'em hang'd, every Mother's Son of 'em.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Pick-p.
sp.p: You'll do, Sir, a mighty piece of Service to the Nation: We'll wait on you with a Liſt of their Names, at a more convenient time; till then, your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Yours—Look to your ſelf, Trap, as we walk home; for theſe kind Gentlemen were pleaſed to inform me, the Town is full of Cheats and Rogues:—Wou'd I could catch ſome of 'em with their Hands in my Pockets, I'd preſently ſay to my Sword,—Sword! out of the Scab-board.—O, I am Robb'd! By the Univerſity, Robb'd!—my Sword:—My Purſe!—Nay, the very Speech for my Miſtreſs, is gone too! I am Undone! I ſhall not be Marry'd this Week! Alack! Alack!
sp.stage: [Makes as if he was going to draw.
sp.p:
I am ſafe; that's well: Come, Sir, you are gull'd, I ſee; but if the Speech be the worſt of your Loſs, I warrant you there is Learning enough upon my Shoulders to make a new one: Pox o' your
Books! how heavy they are!—'tis well for you, you do not load your Memory with 'em: D'Zlife! Cou'd you not, like the reſt of the Scholars, leave your Learning behind you?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: O ſweet, honey Trap, I ſhall never have ſo fine a Speech again, there was no leſs than three Acts of Parliament quoted in it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But pray now, have you done? Shall we march on? leſt your kind Gentlemen return, and eaſe me of my Burthen.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Ay, Trap; Ay; only this by way of Caution; Be ſure to ſend Word immediately to dear Lucy, Not to take any manner of notice of me, when I come to court her Miſtreſs: I'll be for her again, tell her, as ſoon as I have got Mrs. Meanwell, that ſweet Bird of Love, into the Cage of Matrimony; till then, Trap, no Syllable, pray, of any Night-Adventures.

sp.speaker: Trap,
sp.p: Oh, there you are out, Sir; with Submiſſion, I think it your Intereſt, the thing ſhould be known.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Fie, Trap, Fie; 'twould ſpoil my Marriage.

sp.speaker: Trap,
sp.p: 'D'Zlife! quite contrary: Believe me, Sir, a Lover is valued by his Miſtreſs, as a Soldier by his General, the better for his Experience.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: But for all your fooling, Trap, if Sir Timothy ſhould examine you about my Intrigues, don't you be ſuch a Buzzard, as to own, it was upon ſome ill Deſign: Tell him only, That having often heard, that the meeting of two Maiden-heads, begetteth commonly a Fool; I thought it prudence in me, to take care, the Son and Heir of my Family ſhould not be ſo unlike my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Trap,
sp.p: Oh! If ſo, then by all means, your future Spouſe ſhould uſe the ſame Caution; for then your Children would be wonderful Wiſe:—But come, Lead on, pray.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh, my Speech! 'twas a rare one:—
Oh, my Sword! 'twas a pure Blade.—

div.head: SCENE Changes to Sir Maurice's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: This Mrs. Catchat has a great Influence over the Lady Meanwell, her Siſter; and if I can make her our Friend, ſhe'll be a good Advocate for us: I'll try—
Suffer, Madam, a paſſionate Lover to make uſe of this Opportunity, to diſcover to you the ſincere—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, Hold; Not ſo faſt, pray: Don't explain your ſelf too freely yet; there are Rules of Decency to be obſerv'd in every thing:

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: That's true, Madam: But my Paſſion is grown to ſuch a heighth, that—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I know well enough, Sir, that you love me, ſigh, and dye for me; yet let me tell you, 'tis both prudent, and diſcreet, I ſhould pretend Ignorance, at leaſt for a time.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, give me leave but to open my Heart to you, and you'll be ſatisfied, that my—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Believe me, Clerimont, an eaſie Conqueſt affords but little Glory: You ſhall value my Heart the better, if I make you pull and tugg hard for it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But ſtill you miſtake my Meaning, Madam; I'll explain my ſelf better, and make you ſenſible, that what I wiſh ſo impatiently for, is only—

sp.speaker: Catch,
sp.p: What! Would you come to a Concluſion ſo very quick? Fye, Clerimont, 'tis againſt the Rules. What had become of the reſt of the Romance, had Mandana yielded preſently to Grand Cyrus; or, Claelia fled into the Arms of Aronces at the firſt Intimation of his Love?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Let not your Heart, Madam, be ſo alarm'd; you have no violence to fear from me: I can aſſure you, Mariana is the only Object of my Deſires; and I want nothing to compleat my Happineſs, but Sir Maurice's Conſent, with the Favour of your Aſſiſtance towards it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Oh Sir, this Shift I muſt hugg you for;—'tis the prettieſt ever came into a witty Man's Head. I admire your Invention; and vow in all the Romances I ever read, I hardly met with any thing more Ingenious, or better contriv'd.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: This is Matter of Fact, Madam, and not of Wit: 'Tis Mariana I love, 'tis Mariana has the ſole Empire of my Heart, and to obtain her is my higheſt Ambition.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Ah, good Sir, D'Autres, I underſtand, well enough, what it is you mean, under the diſguiſed Name of Mariana. Poor Creature! She is but a Pretence I ſee; and indeed, as the caſe ſtands, 'tis well for you, Clerimont, you are not in Earneſt with her; for to my knowledge, ſhe is a Manhater.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! Why muſt you ſo deceive your ſelf, as not to believe what is Truth, and fancy Things that are not?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: No more Grimaces, as you love me; pull off the Vizard, Clerimont, and be not aſham'd to own a Paſſion which your Looks cannot conceal.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Madam, I proteſt—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Nay, proteſt what you will, you ſhall ſigh a little longer: 'Tis not for the Credit, and Reputation of my Charms, to take pity of a Man ſo ſoon;—tho' I confeſs, were I to break a Rule, there is ſo muſt Honeſty in that Phyſiognomy of yours, that I could almoſt be tempted to—
sp.stage: [Looking with a languiſhing Air upon him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Keep to your Rules, Madam, I entreat you; but do not go on in your Errour.

sp.speaker: Catch,
sp.p: Adieu Clerimont, let this ſuffice for once; I have, I fear, diſcover'd too much Weakneſs already: 'Tis time for my Modeſty to make an honourable Retreat.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What, go undeceived! and ſtill running on in that Extravagant Humour,—Madam, I tell you—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Pray forbear, Sir, and be not ſo preſſing: Surely you don't deſign to offer Violence to my Honour.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: May I periſh, Madam, if I have ſuch a Thought.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I'll hear no more, au revoir—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Hang me, Madam, if I love you, your—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, 'tis in vain,—au revoir—
Pox of her Fancies: I never met with any thing ſo impertinent in my Life. When a vain Woman is in Love, ſhe muſt, for her own Credit, perſwade her ſelf ſhe is belov'd.

q.l: And ſpeaking Truth in Love, we're not believ'd,
All Women like in this, to be deceiv'd.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I Am over-joy'd at the News, Brother; for his Father and I, were intimate Friends, and fellow Soldiers under Monk. You may aſſure Clerimont, that I ſhall be Proud of the Honour of his Alliance—

But here comes my Siſter; let's hear what ſhe ſays to it. You come in very good time, Siſter, to give your Opinion about a Match for my Daughter. Clerimont is the Man my Brother propoſes: And I am ſo far ſatisfied with his Character, that I give my Conſent to it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: My Brother Meanwell cannot be in Earneſt ſure. I know the thing is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: How now, Siſter, What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Nothing Brother, but only that you are impoſed, prettily impoſed upon; that's all. The Gentleman's Heart, to my knowledge, is deeply enga'd ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: You are in a merry Humour, Siſter: What's the meaning of this Fooling? Pray, Is not Clerimont in Love with my Niece?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I have Reaſon to think he is not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: D'Zlife! I have it from his own Mouth, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah, poor Brother! How I pity your Ignorance!

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: What-a-Pox! Did not he juſt now deſire me to propoſe the Match to Sir Maurice? you doat ſurely.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah, this Plot won't take, Brother, you muſt think again.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: The Woman is mad with her Laughing. Where's the Jeſt of it pray?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: No Jeſt at all, but very good Earneſt I aſſure you Will you have it? here it is. Clerimont's Love is a Myſtery, revealed, as yet, to none but me: But I'll be ſo kind, perhaps, as to open your Eyes, that you may ſee your Errour.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Ay do: Since you pretend to know things ſo well, let's hear a little, where it is his Affections are ſo deeply engag'd?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: But tell me firſt, Have you a Curioſity to know it?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Surely, I think it do's concern us all to be better inform'd about it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Shall I name the very Perſon?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Ay, ay, by all means; I'm impatient.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Well, ſince you deſire it ſo earneſtly, know Brothers, 'tis my ſelf.
sp.stage: Fanning her ſelf, and looking big.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: What you! That's a very good Jeſt in troth. Siſter, Siſter, Do you know no body in Town to put this upon, but your own Brothers? Ha! ha! ha!
sp.stage: Sir Maurice, and Meanwell, fall a Laughing.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Bleſs me Sirs! What means all this Wonder? You laugh, and ſtare, juſt as if I had ſaid ſomething extraordinary. What do you ſee in me pray, that's ſo very deſpicable? I am, thank God, ſo made, as not to need complain of Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I vow, Brother, we have been under a ſad Miſtake all this while; we never knew before, we had a Beauty in our Family.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I know, poor Souls, if you don't, who it is can yet kill with a Frown, and Fetter with a Smile.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Siſter, the World is blind.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: All the World is not Brother,—Freeman, Belair, Courtall, Valentin, Beaugard, Dorimant, Belamour, ſtand, I think, in ſpite of Envy, as ſo many living Trophies to my conquering Charms.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! all theſe love you, Siſter, don't they?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Love me! yes, I think they do;—and beſides theſe, a great many more, tho' I ſay it. I could once have muſter'd a whole Regiment of 'em; for beſides thoſe, my Scorns have diſpatch'd, the Wars have robb'd me of ſome, and the reſt I have diſcarded.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: But pray once in your Life deal Ingeniouſly with us. Did ever any of theſe Gentlemen tell you, they were really in Love with you?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: None ever durſt take ſo much Freedom with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Freeman, I hear, gives the worſt Characters of you, and ridicules you in all Companies.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: That's only to diſguiſe his Paſſion, and deceive the World the better.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: But what's the Reaſon we never ſee Courtall here?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: 'Tis to ſhew the greateſt Reſpect.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Valentin, of late, makes violent Love to Florimel.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: The Gentleman was forward, and that's the Penance I impoſe on him for a Month.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: But what if he ſhould fall to it in earneſt, and bid adieu to your conquering Charms?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I don't fear him, Brother; he values Beauty too much, to forſake me.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Belamour, to my knowledge, is Marry'd to Philinda.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: 'Twas Deſpair drove him to it.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Beaugard, I hear, keeps a Miſs at Greenwich.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I allow him to acquaint himſelf with Vice, that he may value my Vertue the more.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: As for Dorimant, there is but little Hopes of him: He was always a deſperate Woman-Hater.

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: He was ſo, Brother, before he ſaw me: He is not the firſt Convert my Looks have made.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: And as for Belair, you know well enough, Siſter, that he profeſſes himſelf an inveterate Enemy to ſtale Virginities.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: The more Hopes for me then.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: O' my Conſcience, Siſter, theſe are all Viſions.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Nothing but Chimera's of her own.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Ay, Chimera's! Viſions! Viſions and Chimera's! nothing but Chimera's! Very well; I am glad of the Chimera's; I did not know before, I had Viſions and Chimera's.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: O' my Conſcience, Womens Heads, now a-days, are ſo ſtuff't up with their Traſh of Romances and Poetry, that there is no room left in 'em for Reaſon, or Common Senſe: Our Siſter is Mad; ſtark Mad, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: She has got the Trick of Old Maids, poor Creature; ſhe builds Imaginary Trophies of Love upon the Ruins of her Beauty; and ſets as good a Face as ſhe can upon her Sorrows, whil'ſt inwardly ſhe is a continual Prey to uneaſie Thoughts, and conſuming Deſires; to knawing Deſpair, and tearing Remorſe: I pity her with all my heart.—But to return; I have engag'd to give Clerimont an Anſwer: Shall he have Mariana, or ſhall he not?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Why do you ask again, Brother? I have conſented to it already.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Then let's in, and joyn your Lady's Conſent to yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: What need of that, pray? Have I not paſs'd my Word to you?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: That's true, Brother; but ſtill 'twou'd not be amiſs, I think, before I deliver my Meſſage, I were ſure of her Approbation too; for you know, ſhe is ſo—

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: 'Tis needleſs, I tell you; I'll anſwer for my Wife, and take the thing upon my ſelf: Go you, and acquaint Clerimont, that he has my free Conſent, while I diſcourſe with Mariana, who comes out ſeaſonably for that purpoſe
sp.stage: Enter Mariana and Lucy to Sir Maurice.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Come hither, Child, I have pretty News to tell you: Do you know one Clerimont?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I have heard of him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: What Character has he?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The World allows him to be a Man of Wit and Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I am glad your Account agrees with mine; for I have ſome Thoughts of making him my Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, raviſhing News! Pardon me, dear Sir, if I have done ill, in concealing from you till now, that this ſame Clerimont you named, has already ſhewn ſome Inclination for me; the return of which, I am glad to find, is by your Conſent approved of.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: You miſtake me, Child; 'tis for your Siſter Lovewit, and not for you, I have given my Word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! what is't I hear?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Is there any thing in this, ſeems ſo ſurpriſing to you, Child?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is it poſſible Clerimont ſhould be ſo Unfaithful?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: What means this great Concern?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Support me, Lucy; I ſhall Faint.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Come, Child, be not ſo concern'd; this was only to try you, and ſee if your Love to Clerimont is as great as the Eſteem I have for him: He has my Conſent to make his Addreſſes to you; uſe him you as a Lover.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I receive the Bleſſing on my Knees; and thank Heav'n, my Duty and Love are reconciled.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I underſtand my Wife deſigns you for young Mr. Witleſs; but he'll come too late I aſſure him: however, I muſt receive him civilly, and amuſe him for a while, the better to ſecure our Project

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Her Ladyſhip, I'm afraid, will make uſe of all her Power and Rhetorick to oppoſe my Wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I'd fain ſee that.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Ay, well ſaid, Sir: Don't let her great Words frighten you?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: A pretty thing, indeed! a Husband ſhould mind what a Wife ſays.
Sir Timothy Witleſs, and his lubberly Son, are juſt come in; and I made halfe before 'em, to obſerve how my Rival receives the firſt Complements of her new Lover.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Timothy Witleſs, and Witleſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Sir Maurice, this is my Son Tim, of whom Fame has told you ſo much already.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Mr. Witleſs, your Servant; I can hardly Expreſs how glad I am to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Now Tim. for your Complements.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Is it not expedient, Sir, I ſhould begin with the Father?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay; by all means.
sp.stage: [Witleſs ſpeaking like a School-Boy, and acting with his Hands, addreſſes himſelf to Sir Maurice,]
sp.p: Sir, I come to ſalute, acknowledge, cheriſh and reverence in you a ſecond Father; but a ſecond Father to whom I am more indebted than to my firſt; the firſt Begot me, but you Chuſe me; I was his by Neceſſity, but you accept me by Favour: what I received from him, was but the mere Operation of the Body; but what I have from you, is the free Emanation of the the Will; and by how much more the noble Faculties of the Mind exceed the common Endowments of the Body, by ſo much more alſo do I value that honourable Alliance, for which I am now come to pay you my profound and reſpectful Homage.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Nothing like a College, Madam, for Wit.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Have I performed well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: To a Miracle, Tim.—Now for the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Muſt I Kiſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Boy; they expect it:
sp.stage: [Witleſs goes up to Lovewit, whom he miſtakes for the Mother, ſalutes her, and then ſpeaks to her:
sp.p: Madam, your Right of Maternity—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Odds bodikins, Tim. you are out;—that is not the Mother.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Where is ſhe then?—'Tis none of my fault, ſure?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: My Wife will be here preſently, Mr. Witleſs.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Shall I ſtay, Father, till ſhe comes to receive my Speech?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: You may in the mean time harangue your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: There ſtands a Lady, Sir, waits impatiently for your Complement.
sp.stage: [Witleſs puts his Speech into his Hat, and ſometimes looks on Mariana, ſometimes on the Speech; and ſays,
sp.p:
Madam, As the Statue of Memnon gave an harmonious Sound, when the Rays of the Sun reflected on it; in a like manner do I find my ſelf animated with a raviſhing Tranſport, at the glorious Appearance of the Sun-ſhine of your Beauty:—Give me leave then, Madam, to lay at the Altar of your Charms, the Offering of that Heart, ambitious only of the Honour of
being, Madam, your moſt loving and devoted Servant and Husband, Timothy Witleſs, of Clare-Hall.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Hey-day! Who would grudge Studying hard, to ſay ſuch fine things.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Witleſs, What do you think of my Daughter? Is ſhe not a pretty Book for you to turn over?

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: the Lady is a Beauty in Folio.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Dear, this is Mr. Wittleſs I preſent to you.
Wittleſs to the Lady M. Madam your Right of Maternity.—

sp.speaker: Lady M. Sir,
sp.p: I am glad my auſpicious Stars, have, by their benign Influence, directed my Steps to this place,—that I might—

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: Madam, your Right of Maternity,—your Right of Maternity—becauſe of her Portion,—Pretty Sons, and Daughters, I like her very well.—Humph,—Madam, you have interrupted me in the middle of my Period, and that has confounded my Memory.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Tis very well, Sir. Daughter, this is the individual Gentlemen, Fate has decreed, and I pronounce, your Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: What! dear Duck! before Sir Timothy, and I have examined into Matters?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Duck! fough! What a ruſtick and mean Expreſſion is there?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Well, then my walking Univerſity, my puzling Library of Fleſh, give me leave to tell you, things of this Nature deſerves ſome conſideration.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: That's good indeed with People that need ſecond Thoughts: But where quick Imagination, and profound Judgment meet, the firſt do as well. I have reſolv'd it ſhall be ſo; no more words pray: I expect your compliance.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: But, Why muſt we precipitate things in this manner? Why not give 'em time to know one another? Are you ſure their Inclinations will agree?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Marriage may breed Love; they muſt try.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: On my word, Lady, if Marriage has that Effect with them, they'll have better Luck than I.

sp.speaker: Wittl. to Mar.
sp.p: For my part, Madam, I'm ready.

sp.speaker: Sir. Tim.
sp.p: Spoke like a Man, Tim.
sp.stage: [Sir Maur. claps him on the Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And for my part, Sir, I am not: I muſt freely own to you, that your Merit has not yet made an Impreſſion deep enough in me.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: There is ſuch a Sympathy of Features in our Two Faces, that my Heart tells me, we were made one for another.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marriage is ſo laſting a Bondage, that ſurely it ſhould be beneath the Character of a Man of Honour, to wiſh under it a Perſon he Loves.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: Nego Conſequentiam, Madam, I may be Man of Honour, and yet conſent to receive you of the Hands of your Parents.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A Woman's Heart proves commonly a Rebel, which was taken from her by Violence.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.]
sp.p: Tim. Tim. fair Means are beſt.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: We read in the Ancients, Madam, that there was a laudable Cuſtom amongſt 'em, to raviſh Daughters out of their Father's Houſes, to the end it ſhould not appear, that they had, of their own accord, fled into the Arms of a Man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Ancients, Sir, are dead, and we live; we can ſave our Modeſty without their Cuſtoms: And when a Match is offer'd, we know how to expreſs our Liking to it, without offending againſt the Rules of Decency. Give me, Sir, but a little time: If you love me, as you pretend, you muſt have no other Will but mine.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, to the Intereſt of my Love Excluſively.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But ſure the greateſt Inſtance of Love, in a Complaiſant Lover, is to ſubmit, without reſerve, to the Pleaſure of his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: Diſtinguo, Madam; where the poſſeſſion of her Perſon is not concern'd, Concedo; but where it is, Nego.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſince you want Complaiſance to allow me time to conſider, I'll not want Prudence to take it my ſelf. I am not for Marrying in ſuch haſt, nor before my Father has declared his Mind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lovew. to the Lady.
sp.p: My Siſter you ſee, Madam, had rather rely upon her Fancy, than truſt to better Eyes for a Choice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Siſter, if my Father will not give me the Man I love, I ſhall beg of him, at leaſt, not to force me to Marry one I hate.

sp.speaker: Lady M. to Sir Maur.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Sir Maurice, grows every Day ſo Giddy, and ſo exorbitantly Rude, that no polite Soul can bear with her Effrontery: but I'll take her to Task, and teach her a Se connôitre.—
sp.stage: Enter Catchat, follow'd by Sir Maggot Jingle.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Make room, make room for the Virgil of our Age.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What! my old Lover, Sir Maggot Jingle, I am in an Extaſie for Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Pox of their Jingle, and his ſcandalous Title: Muſt that ſtarving paraſitical Knight be always rhiming and bawling at my Table. Curſe on him! One may know by his Viſits, better than by the Clock, when 'tis Dinner-time at my Houſe.—Sir Timothy, I think you and I have nothing to do here, Had not we beſt go in, and take a Pipe in my little Room?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir Maurice.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: The Ladies will take care of Mr. Witleſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Maur.
sp.p: Mr. Witleſs, let me have the Honour of preſenting you to this Darling of the Muſes, this younger Brother of Apollo, Sir Maggot Jingle.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: What, Madam, the Famous Sir Maggot Jingle that writ that Incomparable Poem of the Fox?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: The very ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wittleſs.
sp.p: Oh Sir! for the ſake of the Fox, let me embrace you, as long as there are Men that love to hunt after Wit and Fancy; your Fox will be ſure to be run to Poſterity.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jingle,
sp.p: Sir your moſt Humble: I do not love to commend my ſelf; but I take that Piece to be a Non ultra in the kind.

sp.speaker: Witleſs.
sp.p: What pity 'tis, Sir, the Court does not underſtand your Merit.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: I am now favouring the ungrateful World, with a rare Collection of my Songs; for without Vanity let it be ſpoken, I am the beſt Lyrick Poet in England.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: How Wittily his Muſe expreſſes her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady Maur.
sp.p: I'm now in my Element—Nimble bring Chairs.—There lies a Booby now, for want of underſtanding the Aequilibrium of Things.
sp.stage: [Nimble brings a Chair, and falls with it.

sp.speaker: Nimble.
sp.p: And ſo this, I ſaw it, as ſoon as I was down.

lg.l: 'Tis well for you, Son of an Aſs,
Nature did not make you of Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What! an impromptu with ſo much Wit! Wonderful!

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Surely this Man is the Phoenix of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Well Ladies, Is the Day fix'd for the opening of your Academy of Beaux Eſprits.

sp.speaker: Lady Maur.
sp.p: Tueſday is the Day, Sir Maggot.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Woe then to the Royal Society; the Glory of it will ſuffer a manifeſt Eclipſe.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Maggot, we will not be ſo Cruel neither to thoſe Gentlemen as to refuſe to join to our Learned Body, the moſt able Mathematicians amongſt 'em; to the end, that by a free Communication of our Diſcoveries, we may penetrate together into ſuch dark Secrets of Nature, as have hitherto been deem'd unfathomable by humane Capacity.

sp.speaker: Lady Maur.
sp.p: Our Society ſhall be as the Inquiſition, a Tribunal without Appeal, or Mercy; where, with a Sovereign Authority, we ſhall Judge of all Books that come out: No Authors ſhall write well, but thoſe we approve of; and no body pretend to Wit, but we, and our Friends.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But you, Sir Maggot, has your witty Muſe conceiv'd of late: What News pray rom Apollo's Levce?

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Very little, Madam, that deſerves to be named to ſuch Sappho's of our Age, as I ſee here.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Come Sir Maggot, no Compliments: You know we had rather hear fine things, than our ſelves commended.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: This is another impromptu, Ladies only made at leiſure.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Oh! I ſhall fall into a Swoon.—

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jingle.
sp.p: Hum, Hum, Hum.—

div.p: To the Counteſs of Squeezingham, upon her AGUE.

lg.l: Your Prudence ſurely, is aſleep,
Whilſt you magnificently treat;
And in your rich Apartment keep
Your cruel Enemy in ſtate.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh the Jantee Beginning.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: What a gallant Turn is there!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nothing can be more degage.

lg.l: Ah force it out, ſay what they will,
From your Apartment, rich and rare;
Th' Ʋngrateful that attempts to kill,
And rob you of a Life ſo fair.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh give me leave to breath,

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I am all Rapture, I vow.—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what a pretty Metaphor that rich Apartment is.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: The Parentheſis, in my mind, is worth a Million.—Force it out, ſay what they will, it implies a Challenge, a Defiance to Criticks.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I'd freely give my Portion to be the Author of a Thing, ſo much out of the common Road.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: What follows, Ladies, will not diſgrace the beginning I'm ſure.

lg.l: What! thus regardleſs of your Race,
In your high Blood it ſelf to place!
And Night and Day torment you ſo.

l.hi: Though it has all this Favour found,
Oh, yet at length ſome Anger ſhow;

lg.l: And when next to the Bath you go,

l.hi: With your own Hands let it be drown'd.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I die away! Support me! Oh, Support me, ſome body! Alas! Alas!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I'm loſt in Pleaſure!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Though it has all this Favour found; though you have indulg'd it, humour'd it ſo long—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Oh, yet at length ſome Anger ſhew; ſome Paſſion, ſome Indignation, ſome Reſentment for its Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: With your own Hands let it be drown'd:—That is, Take hold of it, Madam, and plunge it into the Water—Oh! Oh!—

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: VVell, Mr. Witleſs, did you ever hear the like! VVhat do you think now the Author of ſo excellent a Piece deſerves?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: VVhat he deſerves, Madam?—He deſerves to be Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: What, Sir, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, by Jupiter Ammon; but I warrant him, a moſt illiterate Ais; a mere Rhiming Ideot, without the leaſt Tincture of Philoſophy in him.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: You are too ſevere, Mr. Witleſs; the Author is a Man noted for Wit among us.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: That's all one to me; I maintain him Guilty of High-Treaſon againſt Ariſtotle: VVho in the Devil's Name, ever heard of an Ague being a Tangible Body, and ſubject to Drowning?

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: I am confident, Sir, no Man can write better Verſes than theſe; and my reaſon for it, is, becauſe I am my ſelf the Authour of 'em.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: VVhat you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; my ſelf in Perſon.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: The more ſhame for you, Sir.—Look you Ladies, I'll make you a Copy of Verſes upon any Subject you'll name, only to let you ſee the difference between a Poet and a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Then write a Madrigal upon a Box o' the Ear.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Meaning me, Sir?— [after a little muſing,] —And ſo I will—

lg.l: Sir Maggotty Jingle

l.hi: Did make my Ear tingle;
Which was to me an Affront:
But ſtrait for his Box
I wiſh'd him the Pox;
So had the better on't.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p:
VVhat? do you Laugh? you Chimney-Sweeper of Parnaſſus!—Tho' I take a Box o'th' Ear; I have too much Honour to put up a Jeer: By
the Scull of Chaucer, I'll Rhime thee Black and Blue.—Come if you dare! you Poet Laureat of Bedlam.
sp.stage: [Witleſs lays his Sword aſide, and offers to Box with Sir M. Jingle.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: In the Name of Apollo, I charge you to keep the Peace.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Thank the Lady, Muſhroom, that you live.—And now Ladies, to convince you, that a ſneaking Rhiming Knight, is but an Owl to a Scholar, Here, Here's a piece of VVork, for One that has been at Cambridge but Fours Years and Three-quarters.
sp.stage: [Witleſs offers a roll'd Sheet of large Paper to Lady M.

sp.speaker: Sir. M. Jing.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Madam, I'll ſave your Ladyſhip the trouble of Reading. Sir. M. takes the Paper.

And Exact and Accurate MAP, containing the moſt Curious and moſt Remarkable Signs upon the Road between Cambridge and London, with their ſeveral Motto's, Inſcriptions and Devices, as they were faithfully taken and delineated by Timothy Witleſs, Batchelor of Arts, in his late Travels.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: By Apollo, the thing is new and ſingular—Hah! Hah! Hah!

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: You may look, Ladies, and wonder: I can ſay, that for my ſelf, there is a thing now, Sir Francis Drake neverthought of in all his Travels at Sea.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: For my part, I am charm'd with the curious Drawing.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: And well you may, Lady: for to tell you the truth, I have, in all my Fancies, a huge ſtroke of the Antients:—Look you; All theſe fine Proſpects you ſee here, I have copied from a famous Landskip, drawn, to the beſt of my Memory, five Years before the Flood.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, do you know what Country-man the Painter was.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: A Foreigner, to be ſure, by his way of Drawing: I think he was Painter in Ordinary to the King of Venice; his Name begins with an (&c.) but truly, I have forgot it now.

sp.speaker: Nimble,
sp.p: Madam—Dinner is upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Mr. Witleſs, you'll do us the favour to go in.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Sir Maggot, for the ſake of the Ague, be you my Gueſt to day.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Agreed:—

div.l: A hearty Meal muſt make our Works compleat;
A Poet lives to Write, and Writes to Eat.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: HIS Steward's Place, ſayeſt thou? Faith, no News in the World could have been more welcome; for beſides that I have a natural Inclination to Miſchief, Sir Timothy was pleas'd, juſt now, to give me warning to be gone to morrow, only for being at my arrival a little too familiar with that habitual Sin of his, Mrs Heart-eaſe, his Houſe-keeper, and I was almoſt mad for an opportunity to be revenged of him.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p:
Hold, Jack, Hold; here comes the Gentleman; make your beſt Honours to your beſt Maſter.—
[Preſents Trap to Cler. This Creature you ſee here, Sir, is that worthy Brother of mine, whoſe Skill and Zeal to do you Service, I have already commended to you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
He does not look as if he were a Man of Scruples: I dare anſwer 〈◊〉 his Phyſiognomy, That his Conſcience can diſpenſe with a little Rogu •
〈…〉 do a Man a Kindneſs: But has he the heart to ſerve his Maſter's Riva •
〈…〉

sp.speaker: Trap,
sp.p: For a Maſter, Sir, give me leave to own none but you: 〈…〉 Conſcience, I am as modiſh as the Vicar of Brey; and ſeldom liſten 〈…〉 there's Preferment in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Then let's to Action immediately: What can you think 〈…〉 to give me a taſte of your Wit.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: For my Probation Trick, I have a Plot in hand, will ſtrangely confound and perplex the Witleſſes: but I muſt not foreſtall you with an Account of my Projects; only by way of Prologue to our Comedy, if you have a mind to make your ſelf Sport, and ſerve your Love at the ſame time, I can put you in a way.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: With all my heart:—Let's hear what you propoſe?

sp.speaker: Trap,
sp.p: Mr. Witleſs has order'd me to find out a Dancing-Maſter for him: Let me but introduce you in that Quality, and you'll have a good Opportunity to remove his Affections from your Miſtreſs: the Man is as Eaſie as you can to wiſh; put any thing upon him, I'll anſwer, 'twill take.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I long to be acting of that part; for I was impatient to ſee the Figure of the Man.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Then march about inſtantly; for behold the Enemy appears.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Adieu, pretty Mrs. Lucy: Remember me a thouſand times to Charming Mariana,—You Matchiavel, away to Conſultation.

sp.speaker: Y Catch.
sp.p: I ſay, Mr. Witleſs, that Milk-Sop Babe, my Niece, ſhall not have on; upon my VVord, ſhe ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: She uſed me ſcurvily, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: She does not deſerve a Man of VVit.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: No more ſhe don't, Faith.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I am really ſo ſhagreen, Sir, to ſee a pretty Gentleman abuſed in my Brother's Houſe, that to ſave the Credit of his Family, I am thinking of ſomething to make you amends for his Daughter's Rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: You are exceeding Bounteous, Mrs. Catchat.

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: Look upon me, Mr. Witleſs, and tell me freely, Cou'd you love a VVoman that has liv'd juſt long enough to be VViſe, and make a good Choice?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: 'Tis ſuch a one I long for, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: A Beautiful, Charming Creature.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Faith, you make my Mouth water.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: A VVit, a Critick, an Authour?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Odd'zookers! But where ſhall we find ſuch a Treaſure?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Such a Treaſure is above the Merit and Ambition of Crowned Heads; and yet at your Service, Mr. Witleſs.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh, you raviſh me, Madam! I'm tranſported! Let me ſee that Angel! that Goddeſs! I muſt adore her! VVhere is ſhe? VVhere is ſhe, pray?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Not far, Mr. Witleſs:—Here ſhe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Witl
sp.p: VVhere, Madam? VVhere?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Turn this way, Mr. Witleſs, and fix your Eyes upon me;—'tis my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: VVhat! You, Mrs. Catchat!—And is that Face you have on now, all the Faces you have in the VVorld, pray?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: No doubt on, Sir: And ſurely, whoever has ſuch a One, need not deſire a better.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, to be plain then, that Face of yours is a very unmannerly Face, to give the Lye to ſo fair a Deſcription.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I cannot be angry with One I'm ſure loves me:—Beſides, I muſt tell you, Mr. Witleſs, (though indeed there is little need of any other Charm but my Perſon,) I am a Fortune, Sir;—I have Thouſands, Thouſands, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVittl.
sp.p: Oddzniggs Madam, you ſhould have mention'd that firſt of all.

sp.speaker: Carch.
sp.p: The Mortal I ſhall bleſs with the poſſeſſion of my Perſonal Goods, extrinſick, or intrinſick, ſhall have 4000l. down, and a 1000l. when I am firſt delivered of a Child.

sp.speaker: VVittl.
sp.p: With Submiſſion, that's ill ordered, Mrs. Catchat, it ſhould be a 1000 l. down, and 4000 l. at the fall of the Firſt-Fruit; becauſe the Temptation of the Money, is all the Provocation a Husband is like to have with you, to ſtrive for an Heir.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Bleſs me! the Fellow is a Fool, a perfect Stranger to Wit, and Beauty: I muſt ſtick to my Clerimont; he is a Man of Judgment.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Maggot Jingle, Lady Meanwell, and Mrs. Lovewitt.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Come, Sir Maggot, we will not be put off with a Complement; we'll have the Song.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: To tell you the Truth, I am a little proud of this Piece; look upon it as a very lucky Hitt of my Muſe towards Preferment.—Here it is.—

body.head: SONG.
body.l: SHould King Lewis, with all his might,

l.hi: Thus ſay to me, by chance,

body.l: Reſign thy Peggy for one Night,
And I'll make thee a Peer of France.

l.hi: To the Monſieur, I'd reply,
Her Fleſh thy Royal Paw ſhan't handle.
Keep thy Honour and thy Pelf,

body.l: And I'll keep Peggy to my ſelf,

l.hi: VVho ſhines as bright as any Candle.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Next time Sir Maggot favours us with a Viſit, I hope our Meetings will be regularly fixed.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Do you know, Sir Maggot, that I diſcovered laſt Week, Three Men in the Moon, fighting a Duel in a Church-yard?

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Ay, that I know; and I hear ſince, that he in the Blue Coat was wounded, and drop'd down into a Tub of Yeaſt, at a Brewer's in Bury.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I ſaw the poor Creature fall; and I could not but admire at the other Two, who, inſtead of running away, and making their Eſcape, fell a gazing on me for an Hour together. The Sparks of that ſhining World, are of a loving Conſtitution, I promiſe you; a few Looks of mine would ſoon conſume 'em all; and then my Charms, like Alexander, muſt weep for want of Worlds to Conquer.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: I cannot boaſt of prodigious things, Madam: However, I have now a ſmall piece in the Preſs, will, I hope, appear new to the World; and that's Cook upon Littleton turn'd into Heroick Verſe.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: Now you talk of Projects, Do you know, Ladies, that my Tutor and I, are ſetting up a Penny-Poſt to the Weſt-Indies.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: But you, Mrs. Catchat, what's become pray of your dainty Piece of Work as you call it.?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: What! my Satyr againſt Eunuchs? Fough! I left it unfiniſh'd; the filthy Subject provoked my Spleen, but could not raiſe my Fancy.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: For my part, I love any thing that has a reliſh of the publick Spirit in it: I was yeſterday with my Lord Mayor, to communicate to him a Mathematical Engin of my own, to keep the Streets as clean, and as dry as a drawing Room all the Year round.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: How's this, Madam, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: 'Tis only by ſecuring the City from Rain.

sp.speaker: VVittl.
sp.p: From Rain, Madam! that's impoſſible. How can you compaſs it?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh eaſily enough, Mr. VVittleſs: Tell me, Have you ſeen the glaring Lamps upon the Road to Kenſington?

sp.speaker: VVittl.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, that I have, What then?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Well, juſt ſo, 'tis only ſetting up Timber Poſts round about the City, and then fixing a pair of Bellows upon every one of 'em, to blow the Clouds away.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Sir Maggot, I have now a huge Limbeck making; gueſs for what.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Gueſs ſay you?—Faith I can't, unleſs it be to diſſolve the Philoſophers Stone.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, no, Sir Maggot; 'tis for a more noble Deſign, I aſſure you: You muſt underſtand, that I have made an exact Collection of all the Plays that ever came out, which I deſign to put into my Limbeck; and then extract all the Quinteſſence of. Wit that is in them, to ſell it by drops to the Poets of this Age.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: Oh Madam, Let me beſpeak a few of your witty Drops for the Poor Gentlemen of the Athenian Mercury.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Surely thoſe Oracles of Learning do not want 'em.

sp.speaker: VVittl.
sp.p: Faith but they do: Look you, I propoſed but this to them t'other Day: Suppoſe we ſhould put the Brains of a Scholar into the Head of a Bull, whether or no that Bull would ſpeak Latin as I do? and never truſt me if they knew what to ſay to it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: But why ſhould you think that ſo mighty a Miracle. I my ſelf who ſeldom boaſt of any thing, am now teaching a Flea to ſing: The little Creature underſtands the Notes already; and if I live, ſhe ſhall ſing a Song in the next Opera that's acted.—
sp.stage: Enter Sir Timothy Wittleſs, reeling; and Sir Maurice Meanwell, a little elevated.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: You might have taken t'other Bottle ſure; Why in ſuch haſt Sir Timothy?

sp.speaker: Sir Tem.
sp.p: Look you, Neighbour, when I have Buſineſs of Importance in my Noddle, I love to be Sober: Where is honeſt Tim? Come my Boy, you muſt be marrried to morrow, along along to my Taylor; by the Beard of King Dick, I'll make thee as gay as a Pageant at my Lord Mayor's Show. Ladies your Servant; Sir Maurice your moſt Humble. On, on Boy.

sp.speaker: VVittl.
sp.p: I go, Ladies, and remain your moſt obſequious Slave. My future Progenitor in Law, I reſt for ever your dutiful Son, that is to be.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: I muſt take my leave too, Ladies; for ſome Vertuoſi are to wait on me this Afternoon, about a Scheme I am preparing for the Houſe, to have all the Cities, Towns, and Villages of England, turn'd into Sea-Ports.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Then Sir Maggot your Servant; but pray remember your Promiſe, and fail not at the New Play to morrow; for the Author came Yeſterday to pay his devoirs to us, and we have engag'd for our ſelves, and our Friends, to find it a good one, in ſpite of Rules, and Criticks.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: But tell me firſt, Madam, is the Poet a modeſt, civil Poet; or is he like one of thoſe, that cannot be VVitty without being Obſcene.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: VVhat makes you ask Sir Maggot?

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: 'Tis only for the pleaſure of obſerving ſome nice Ladies of my Acquaintance, who will be ſure never to miſs the firſt Acting of a Play, that if there be any thing high ſeaſon'd in it, they may pleaſe their Palates, and tickle their Fancies with it; and then with a turning up of the Noſe, and a Jeſu had I known the Play was ſo filthy, I would not have ſeen it for a Million: They'll be ſure, for their own Reputation, to cry, the Poet's down; and declaim high againſt thoſe who ſhew ſo little Modeſty, as to ſee it the ſecond Day.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I know the Author, Sir Maggot, and dare engage for the Chaſtity of his Muſe.

sp.speaker: Sir M. Jing.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, Ladies, that the Poet is under your Protection; I'll be at his Play I warrant you, and clap ſtoutly as ſoon as the Candles begin to light.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I thought, Witt Paramount, I muſt have been forced to diſmiſs my ſelf without Audience.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What! Angry? Sir Maurice; I thought you ſtood all the while admiring the Famous Sir Maggot Jingle.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Hang him for a ſcurvy Pimp of Wit, that could never Match Rhime, and Senſe together, a Scoundrel of Parnaſſus, and the very ſcandal of his Trade.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: His Trade! Fough, how Citizen-like is that Expreſſion!

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: A dull Goſſiping, Rhiming Paraſite, who Robs the Piazzas of Paper to Write his Madrigals upon, and ſtands Recorded in Ale-Houſes, for the inſpiring Liquor that makes him a Wit.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Brother, Brother talk with more Reverence of Sir Maggot Jingle, pray, what if his Loyalty to Oliver has made him Poor, he is ſtill a Knight, and a Poet, and ſuch as he, you know, can Fight, and Lampoon.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Faith, Siſter, I fear neither his Sword nor his Satyr, as long as I keep a good Table; for ſuch as he I know, had rather put up an Affront than loſe a Meal.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: How now, Sir Maurice, is the merry God Dancing a Jigg within the incloſure of your Brains? you forget your ſelf ſtrangely methinks.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: 'Tis to you, Siſter, I ſpeak, what a Devil have you to do with Jingling and Poetry.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Lord, Siſter, what a ſtrange compound your Husband is of Vulgar and Clowniſh Atoms?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: A pretty thing indeed, to ſee thoſe long Spectacles of yours, ſet on the Top of my Houſe, for you to peep, and tell how many Hackney Coaches are going in the Moon.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Oh the Illiterate Brute! thus to affront a Teleſcope.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I am no Scholar, not I, and I thank my Stars for it, but with your leave, ſo much common Senſe has taught me, that all the Study and Philoſophy of a Wife, ſhould be to pleaſe her Husband, inſtruct her Children, have a Vigilant Eye over Domeſtick Affairs, keep a good Order in her Family, and ſtand as a Living Pattern of Virtue, and Diſcretion to all about her.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Sir Maurice like another Solon, is now ſetting up for a Lawgiver, Poor Soul!

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: The Women of Old did not read ſo much, but lived better, Houſewifry was all the Knowledge they aſpired to; now adays Wives muſt Write forſooth, and pretend to Wit with a Pox.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: 'Tis the partial, and fooliſh Opinion of Men Brother, and not our Fault has made it ridiculous now adays; for a Woman to pretend to Wit, ſhe was born to it, and can ſhew it well enough, when occaſion ſerves.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Ay, to our Coſt ſometimes, Female Wit Triumphs, and Excels in three things, Revenge, Diſſembling and Cuckoldom; there I grant we muſt yield to you for quickneſs and dexterity.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: But for all your Jeſting Brother, a Man's Wit is as dull as his Appetite, if not ſet an Edge by ours.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Hang your Edging, a Woman's Wit was always a Pimp to her Pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I'm tired Sir Maurice with your Nonſenſe: Satyr does not become a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: But I tell you Lady, that I will have a Reformation in my Houſe, that this Plague of Wit has infected all my Servants, even my little Boy, forſooth, cannot turn the Spit now without a Pharamond, or a Caſſandra in his hand; if I call for Drink, the Butler brings me a Spencer, or a Ben Johnſon.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: If this be all you have to ſay Sir Maurice; Farewel.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: No, Angry Mother of the Muſes, give me but Attention, and you ſhall hear; your Daughters Wit it ſeems is like to ſtarve her Love: I'm told ſhe deſigns to keep Hoſpitality in another World, and Feaſt the worms with her Maiden-Head.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What ſtrange Jargon's this?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: But Mariana being not altogether ſo Witty, but like a ſimple Creature, deſirous to keep Houſe in this World; 'tis time to think of a Husband for her.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: 'Tis what my preventing Wiſdom has already determined; I have engag'd to Sir Timoth, that his Son ſhall be the Man; he is a Perſon of deep parts, and that's in my Opinion the only way to infuſe the Spirit of Improvement into your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Did you not perceive by my Daughters Diſcourſe with Mr. Witleſs, that ſhe has no great liking to him; why ſhould we force her Inclination my Dear.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What now? will you offer to Contradict me; I have paſt my word, and it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I am not ſo much againſt it my deareſt Dear, but only let's do things as they ſhould be done; let's give her a little time at leaſt, to Conquer her Averſion.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: 'Tis pity indeed, but my Determinations ſhould wait for the ſettling of the giddy Thoughts of ſuch an illiterate Creature as your Daughter; I am reſolved it ſhall be as I pleaſe, bid her be ready, for to morrow I'll ſend to Mr. Engroſs to bring the Writings this Evening to Seal.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: But my Dear in a Caſe of this importance.

sp.speaker: Lady Maur.
sp.p: What, again? Hold your Tongue Sir Maurcie, I don't love people ſhould reply.
sp.stage: Enter Meanwell to Sir Maurice, who ſtands hanging his Head in a Melancholy Poſture.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I ſee your Lady going Brother, I ſuppoſe you have had ſome Diſcourſe about the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Yes, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Well, and what's the Reſult of it pray, ſhall we have Mariana? Has ſhe given her conſent, is the thing agreed on?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Not altogether.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Does ſhe deny?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Is the matter left in ſuſpence?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: What then Brother, is it a Myſtery never to be Revealed?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I'll tell you Brother, ſhe ſays that ſhe has engag'd her word for Mr. Witleſs, and cannot recall it.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: And what did you ſay to it pray, did you accept of him?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I! No; God forbid.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: What Anſwer then did you make?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: None at all, and I am glad I did not, for fear ſhe ſhould have diſputed me into a conſent.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: The Reaſon is admirable Brother; but did you at leaſt propoſe Clerimont to her?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: No Brother, I had more Wit I aſſure you; look you, when I heard her Name Mr. Witleſs, I thought my mentioning Clerimont would but Exaſperate her the more.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Your Prudence Brother amazes me, an't you aſhamed of your ſoft, and eaſie temper?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Brother I love Peace, and my Wife is a terrible Dragon when once out of Humout; ſhe makes indeed a High Boaſt of her Philoſophy, but ſhe is not a bit the leſs Cholerick for it, and her Morals that teach her to look upon all things with an indifferent Eye, have not the leaſt Influence upon her Paſſions; ſhe is ſtill Woman all over Brother.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: This is Mockery, perfect Mockery Brother, your VVife Rules becauſe you are faint hearted; take my word 'tis the way of Cunning, and deſigning VVives as ſoon as they are Married, Nicely to ſtudy the Temper of their Husbands, and thence Uſurp Power in proportion to their weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: In ſober ſadneſs I'm to blame, my Neighbours take Notice of it I hear, and I begin to be weary on't. Faith I do Brother.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: For ſhame, good Brother do not make your ſelf ſuch a Ninny, as to ſuffer that puny thing woman to lead you by the Noſe; pluck up a Spirit, ſhew your ſelf a Man; and when your wife has the ill manners to Argue with you, tell her in a Tone of Authority ſuch is my VVill and Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: You are in the right Brother, [Cocking his Hat] come I'm reſolv'd I'll ſhew more Courage for the future.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: VVell ſaid.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: 'Tis a diſgrace for a Man to ſubmit to the Capricious Humour of a wife.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: She has abuſed my Patience too long.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Too much impoſed upon me.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: That's certain.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: And ſhe ſhall know to day, that my Daughter is my Daughter, and that it belongs to me, and to no body elſe, to diſpoſe of her as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Now 'tis as it ſhould be, I am overjoy'd at the change.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: You Know Clerimont's Lodgings, pray call upon him, and tell him, I muſt ſpeak with him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I am going to the Exchange, to hear what News from Hamburgh, for I had notice this morning that our Ship is ſafely arrived, and I'll ſee him as I go.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
HEre he comes, compoſe your ſelf a little, and forbear Laughing if you can—Sir, here's Mr. Le Brall,
[Enter Witleſs.] the beſt Dancing-maſter in Town, is come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Sir, your very profound, humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Your man informs me, Sir, that you have a deſire to learn the graceful motions of our Art, I ſhall be proud of—

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: But firſt tell me, Sir, could I learn to Dance by Grammar? I love to do things methodically.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: That can't be, Sir; for the Perfection, or End of our Art is chiefly to reform the rude, and clowniſh Geſtures of the Body, which is a thing meerly practical.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Whether you know it or no, I can tell you, Sir, your Art is very ancient, I have read ſomewhere in Juvenal, that there was a Ball in Noah's Ark.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, that's but a Trifle, we derive the Pedigree of Dancing much higher.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: But now let's ſee what we have to do, I am ſoon to marry, and I have ſent for you, Mr. Le Brall, to teach me to Dance as curiouſly as you can, for 'twould be a ſhame for a Gentleman, and a Scholar as I am, that any body ſhould outdo me at my own Wedding.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Don't you queſtion, Sir, but I ſhall come off with credit; but pray when is the day?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: To night, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What! ſo ſoon, Sir! you confound me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Don't let that fright you, Mr. Le Brall, my Maſter is not like other People, his Brains circulate to his very Heels; I'll engage for him, that he'll learn as much in two hours, as he would do in a quarter of a year!

sp.speaker: Cler.
