sp.p: Oh, if ſo, we are well enough—Come, Sir, your Hat—So:—Your Shoulders—Very well:—Your Arms—To a marvel:—Hold up your Head—So:—Your right Foot forward—So:—Turn out your Toes—So:—Keep your Body ſtreight—Admirable:—Make your Honours—Nothing can be more exact.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Well, what do you think on't, Maſter? I fancy I do pretty well.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You amaze me, Sir, with your Dexterity.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Don't you think my Miſtreſs will be tranſported to ſee me dance ſo well? You muſt be at the Wedding, Maſter, remember I invite you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: He'll be there I don't queſtion, and one of the chief Actors, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You honour me, Sir; but will you pardon my Curioſity, if I preſume to ask the Lady's Name who is to be ſo happy?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: My Miſtreſs, and future Spouſe, Sir, is one Mrs. Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Which of 'em—Mariana?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: If ſo, then I muſt needs ſay, ſome People have better Luck than they deſerve.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, Sir, I have been too raſh I ſee.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Surely there is ſomething of myſtery in this; pray, good Mr. Le Brall, inform me.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: No, Sir, men of my Profeſſion ought to be ſecret.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: 'Dzlife, I can bear no longer! pray, good Maſter, do not keep me thus in ſuſpence; I ſwear by the Univerſity, your Kindneſs to me ſhall do you no diſſervice.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Upon your word, Sir?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Upon my Word and Honour.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, Sir Maurice is my Friend, Mrs. Meanwell too is one I value; but ſurely when a Perſon of your Character is going to be groſsly cheated even by thoſe he leaſt ſuſpects, I cannot, I muſt not be ſilent, I'll deal frankly with you, Sir, Do you in the buſineſs as you think fit.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh ſweet Mr. Le Brall, how good you are!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: The young Lady, Sir, to my knowledge has an intimate Engagement with a certain Spark, that would make nothing of cutting your Throat, ſhould he by chance diſcover, that you are reſolved to go on in your Amour; ſhe loves him ſo paſſionately too, that I heard her once vow to him, ſhe'll have none but him for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Say you ſo? The poor Fool! how I pity her! I have done with her, I warrant her: What, did the ſilly Creature fancy a Man of my Exploits and Fame can want Women? Bleſs me! the World to me is like the Seraglio to the Grand Signior.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Beſides, I muſt tell you by the by, that her Humour is too French, and Airy, for a man of your ſolid Parts; who knows, but that it may in time degenerate into Coqueterie.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: A word to the Wiſe, I underſtand you, Maſter; the Spark ſhan't out my Throat I warrant him, nor the Jipſey make a Cuckold of me I promiſe her; a Coquet, 'Dzniggers! Let who will take her, the cheating Devil made this morning as if ſhe had been a very reſerved Saint.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Woman, Sir, is a Riddle, a meer Compound of Contradictions, whoſe meaning you'l never find out, but by miſtaking her words.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, there was a narrow Eſcape for us now, thank your Stars and M. Le Brall for it.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh the ſubtle Crocodile! how I hate her! Nay, ſhe is Illiterate too, and underſtands neither Greek nor Latin.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Nay, I fancy ſhe deſpiſes Dancing too, for I have often obſerved her making Faces at her Siſter when I was teaching her.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Then you go to Sir Maurice's ſometimes, Maſter?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Ay, that I do three times a week.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh! what would I give you were there within this hour! for I'm reſolved to go, and give a parting Lecture to that falſe, cunning, jilting, profligate Minx.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I'll endeavour to be there; but pray not a word from whence you had it, you'd ruine me.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Upon the word of a Batchelor of Arts, not a tittle; be there only, and I'll make you Sport I warrant you for this Kindneſs, I'll ſo rattle the little Jade before you—

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: On my Conſcience this is a wicked World; there is no Faith in a Woman, who cheats even with her modeſty.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Mr. Le Brall, remember within an hour—Oh the Devil!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Oh the Woman!

lg.l: Fortune, her Blindneſs, does too plainly ſhow,
When on an Aſs ſhe would her Gifts beſtow;
For though ſhe ſtill deſires, not to forſake him,
A Fool's but what a Man of ſenſe will make him: &c.

div.head: SCENE Sir Maurice's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: PRay, good Aunt, what makes you ſo very earneſt to know, if that Clerimont be quite out of my mind?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Kindneſs to you, Child, nothing elſe; I know he is Engaged ſomewhere elſe, and I would not have you love in vain.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But ſtill what makes you fancy it ſo very difficult a thing for me to hate that man? Have my Words or Looks at any time betrayed ſuch a mighty Paſſion for him?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: He boaſted of it once; how far he had reaſon to do it, you know beſt.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Preſumptuous! And could you that know me, Aunt, believe I ſhould make choice of one, who counts it a ſcandal in our Sex to pretend to Wit?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: No, dear Niece, I could hardly imagine you'd think that man worthy of your Eſteem, who takes all occaſions to Ridicule the excellent Talents the World admires in you.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Unmannerly! he ſpares no body; I hear even your ſelf, Aunt, don't eſcape his Satyr.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Stupid! Whatever Approbation your Poetry meets with among the Wits, he is always the laſt to commend it.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Ignorant! I have twenty times read things of your Compoſing to him, which he could not forbear calling Stuff and Nonſence to my Face:

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Impertinent! I have had a thouſand Quarrels with him upon your account.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: All this, and more perhaps, I could have diſpenſed with, but one thing my Philoſophy could not forgive him, that he had hardly loved me two Years before he began to talk of Marriage—Fough!

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Oh the filthy Beaſt! Fough! it turns my Stomach I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Lord! what a bold and impudent Creature is man, to dare mention the word Marriage to a Woman of Wit and Fortune? For tis no more than with fawning Words, and paſſionate Speeches, to deſire her very civilly to mend his condition, and make her ſelf his Slave.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Faith, Niece, 'tis e'en ſo.

l.hi: For the ſoft Joys of Love no longer laſt,

lg.l: When once the fatal Yea our Lips has paſt;

l.hi: Then we begin to court, and to comply,
And find we only Rule, while we Deny.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Out upon thoſe Treacherous Syrens, cruel and bewitching Monſters, who charm us into Ruine, and greedily devour our Subſtance.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: But what ſay you to this, Niece? I know men in Town, who were born with the beſt Diſpoſitions in the World to make good Husbands, who yet as ſoon as they came to be married, leſt they ſhould be laugh'd at for their Singularity, affected a Peeviſhneſs, which was not natural to them; and rather than their Wives ſhould have the Pleaſure or Benefit of their good Humour, force themſelves into a ſullen Temper; they are true Friends, and merry Companions abroad, but very ill Husbands at home, and make it their buſineſs to appear Good to every body, but their own Wives.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
And muſt I Careſs ſuch an Owl? Muſt I humour ſuch a Fop in every thing? Muſt I obey a Fool, who cannot command his Paſſions, and
thinks a Wife was given him as the Brutes of the Creation, only to ſerve him? No, help me Reaſon, and neither Clerimont, nor any man living, ſhall ever boaſt of my Ruine.
sp.stage: Enter Clerimont, who ſtands behind Lovewit unſeen.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why ſo angry, Madam? What! a Philoſopher, and paſſionate?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Were I as angry as you pretend, Sir I could perhaps find Reaſons to juſtifie my Reſentment; a Heart unfaithful and inconſtant, is a Monſter in Love, as well as Morality.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Can you call that Infidelity, Madam, which was occaſioned by your Slights? 'Tis true, the Sacrifice you diſdain'd, I have ſince offered to another, but ſtill 'tis not I forſook you, 'tis you diſmiſs'd me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: If I deferred to Crown your Wiſhes, 'twas only becauſe you were not indifferent to me; I hoped Time would have improved your Love to the Purity and Perfection of mine, but your Thoughts, I find, cannot keep themſelves free from the filthy Commerce of the Fleſh, nor your Soul reliſh the raviſhing Pleaſure of the Union of two Hearts, when the Body, that nauſeous, naſty Thing, does not come in for a Share.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: It is my misfortune, Madam, to be ſenſible that I have a Body as well as a Soul; your refined Love is a piece of Philoſophy too high for me to comprehend, and my Senſes ſtick a little too cloſe to me, to leave it in my power to ſhake 'em off.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Oh! what a ſtrange ſort of Love you men are for! Surely 'twas deſigned for Brutes only, Creatures inſpired by a Soul Divine ſhould, methinks, raiſe themſelves higher, and not ſuffer the ſweet and fruitful Imagination of Pleaſure to be filthily drown'd in an impure and beaſtly Enjoyment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Platonick Love, Madam, does not agree with my Conſtitution; my Body is a Rebel, and will not always keep ſubject under the Empire of the Mind, I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Well then, ſince there is no other way, ſince your brutiſh Sentiments muſt carry it againſt the Purity of my Reaſons, ſince none but Carnal Fetters will bind you, endeavour to get my Mother's Conſent, I'll try if I can prevail with my Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: No, Madam, it is now too late had this kind Intention of yours—

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I told you as much, dear Niece, but you would not believe me.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: My Heart, Madam, is no more in my power.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I know that well enough.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: If your Heart, Sir, is not in your power, mine is, and I had rather pierce it, than throw it away on one, who does not underſtand the value of it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Poor Niece! ſhe might have ſaved her ſelf all this fretting—I pity the Child with all my Heart——Come, Clerimont, the time of Ceremony is now over, you may ſpeak more freely, I give you leave.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Speak, Madam! I have nothing to ſay, but only, that I muſt take my leave of you, I have a little buſineſs with Sir Maurice within.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I ſee you are an exact Lover, afraid of breaking any of your Miſtreſs's Commands: 'Tis true, I forbid you this Morning to Expreſs your ſelf too paſſionately, but your Modeſty Conquers me: Speak your Heart; do, I will not be Angry.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, all your words are riddles to me.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Nay Clerimont, can you think me ſtupid to that degree, as not to diſcern your Paſſion for me; believe me, there can be no ſhame in Adoring ſuch Beauty as mine: you are not the firſt by a thouſand has counted it an Honour to die for this Face.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why all this Fuſtian to me, Madam? I am neither blind, nor ready to be begg'd for a Fool.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I ſee you are a baſhful Lover; and to give you the greateſt Inſtance of my Condeſcenſion that ever Mortal boaſted of, I will ſave you the Ceremony of a Declaration, and take it for granted, that you die for me; is it not ſo, Clerimont?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I proteſt, Madam, I know nothing of it—How ſhall I get rid of this Devil?
Well, Madam, ſince nothing elſe will ſatisfie you, and a Declaration you muſt have, give me but time till to morrow, and I'll deſire no more.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: This is Formality, I'm ſure, meer Formality, nothing elſe. I know he muſt come to it at laſt, whether he will or no—But come, ſo far I muſt gratifie a Lover.
Adieu, Clerimont; dear Clerimont, adieu till to morrow; I mean, if you can live till then.

sp.speaker: Clerimont.
sp.p: Surely angry Heaven could not have plagued Mankind with a greater Curſe, than theſe fawning, greedy, preying Catchats of our Age, fond, and Libidinous Monſters, who, Proud when young, turn Wanton in their declining; and Nature now revenging her ſelf upon 'em, they are at laſt devoured by that Fire they refuſed to quench before. But I muſt in, leſt the Fool comes, and ſurpriſes me before I have ſeen my Angel.

div.stage: Enter Mariana to Clerimont as he is going in.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: O charming Mariana! you are as welcom to me, as the Sun to a Traveller after a Storm; I have been ſet upon by two loving, perſecuting Devils, who, without any mercy, would have robbed you of my Heart, but I'll defend it for you, as long as it affords me Life to do it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I truſt too much to your Honour and Conſtancy to fear any Rival; but there is a more dangerous Enemy alarms my Love, my Mother-in-Law, who, like a Fury, was juſt now haunting Sir Maurice, to fret and torment him into Compliance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: As you truſt to my Conſtancy, fair Mariana, truſt alſo to my Care and Diligence, the witty Wife ſhall not hector long, the Plot is ripe; and the faithful couple, Trap and Lucy, bid me not doubt of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But as to the Directions you ſent me in your Note.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You know 'tis both to make our ſelves ſport with the Cambridge Ninny, and to remove the Brute; put on for once the Vizard of a Coquet, and you ſhall ſee rare play.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Were it not to ſecure Clerimont to my Wiſhes, I could never have prevail'd with my ſelf to beſtow one kind Word, or ſmiling Look on his Rival.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: This is the only time, Madam, I ſhall ever ask you to diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then let him come when he will, I'll play the Jeſuit for once; and while I throw away fond Speeches upon him, direct my Intention to you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But here comes the Booby—
sp.stage: Enter Witleſs, who affects to look ſullen, and places himſelf between Clerimont and Mariana.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir, I am here beforehand with you; but, I vow, my waiting for you did not at all ſeem tedious to me: Mrs. Meanwell is ſo tranſported at the thoughts of her approaching Happineſs, that ſhe could not forbear telling me a thouſand pretty things of her Love, or boaſting pleaſantly, how bleſſed ſhe'd ſoon be in a Husband.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, you a Lover, Sir! and ſo long from your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Softly, ſoftly, Madam! [To Cler.] She comes on rarely.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Did not I tell you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: [Looking on Cler.] Oh! how raviſh'd, how tranſported am I! to ſee the man my Heart adores; I would not change for an Empire the Bleſſing of ſo charming a ſight.

sp.speaker: Witl. to Cler.
sp.p: Oddzookers! how brisk ſhe is, ſhe takes fire in a moment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Stand upon your Guard, Sir; ſtand upon your Guard, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh! I ſee Love playing in his Eyes, and little Cupids hid in every Smile.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: By the Univerſity, ſhe is Romantick!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh! how impatiently do I live, till I am yours.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: 'Dſlife, ſhe begins to grow uneaſie!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: No doubt of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: to Cler. Defer my Happineſs no longer if you love me, you are ſure of my Heart; why ſhould you deſire any further Tryal of my Conſtancy?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Hold, Lady Pert, hold, not ſo quick, I pray, I am not the Fool you imagine; thank our Stars, the Witleſſes are noted in the World for Brains; I won't be caught, not I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What means my dear Heart, why ſo alarm'd?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: What do I mean, ſay you? I mean, that you ſhan't make a Cuckold of me, by the Univerſity you ſhan't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bleſs me! why ſuch Diſcourſe, my pretty Fool?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Fool your ſelf—That's all, forſooth; I did not know you before; but I am pretty well informed now what you are, I'll not marry a Coquet, not I— [To Cler.] There I touch'd her Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: to Cler. Oh! 'tis all in vain, I love none but you, and none but you will I ever have.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Stop there, ſays Tim, I'll take care of that Miſs, the Witleſſes ſhall never Reproach me for bringing Infamy into their Honourable Family.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: [Making as if ſhe were crying.] Oh! I can hold no longer, you are too barbarous, Tygers are not more Unnatural than you are.

sp.speaker: Cler. to Witl.
sp.p: Why ſo ſevere upon the Lady, Sir?—I am ſorry now I was the occaſion of this, I proteſt I am.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Let her cry, what's that to me? Look you, Maſter, Marcus Tullius Hudibras ſays, That Women's Tears are like the Crocodile's, ſhed only to pity Fools into Ruine.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But, Sir, Methinks the tenderneſs of the Sex—

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Le Brall, let her blubber out her Venom. Did you never hear the ſaying of the wiſe man in Plutarch; When Dogs fall a ſnarling, Serpents a hiſſing, and Women a crying; the firſt means to bite, the ſecond to ſting, and the third to deceive?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, your Suſpicions do me an injury.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I'll take care, Mrs. Liquoriſh, your Frolicks ſhall do me none.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But won't you hear me, Mr. Witleſs?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Hear you! no—I'll have nothing to do with you, my Soul abhors you. Farewel coqueting, cheating, canting, cozening Flirt, farewel to you for ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And farewel to you, my dear Fool.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You have acted your part to a miracle, the Coxcomb ſeems to be pretty well cured of his Love; however, for fear of a Relapſe, I'll Encourage honeſt Trap to go on in his Projects.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Maurice diſturbed, and in a fright.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh! are you there?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Well, Sir, have your Arguments prevailed? May I flatter my ſelf with the hopes that your Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh! my Wife is a Devil, a very Devil, Sir; ſhe uſes Magick on my Conſcience, it cannot be otherwiſe when I am from her, no man has more Courage than I, I fell my ſelf full of Spirit and Reſolution, but I am no ſooner got to her again, but three of her words, like a Spell, turn me into a Coward; I tried but juſt now, and as ſhe ſpoke, I proteſt, methought I heard Hell roaring, I ran away for fear.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: This Devil might be reſiſted, Sir, if you would.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O dear, Sir! will you then give over? Will you leave your helpleſs Daughter expoſed thus to—

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p:
What would you have me do? You would not have me encounter Hell ſurely, would you? O Citizens, Citizens! how much better for a Wife is a quiet Fool, than a witty Scold!
[Perceiving Lady M. coming out, ſtarts
on a ſudden.] Alack, alack, the Storm is a coming—Do you but ſtand in that corner, and you'l ſee how ſhe plays the Devil.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Meanwell, thruſting out Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Be gone, Trapes, be gone, and be never ſo daring, as to ſhew your Face in my Houſe again.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Alack, alack! ſhe is come to conjure, I ſee a Devil before me already.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's the matter now, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You may ask my Lady, for ſhe turns me away, and will not tell me why.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Come, my dear Angel, my Paradiſe, don't be ſo ſevere to Maiana's maid, ſhe is a good Servant, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: How now, Salomon of the City, will you offer to take her part?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh Lord! not at all, my Dear, I only ask what it is ſhe has done.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What? Am I then to give Reaſons for what I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I do not ſay you are, my Jewel.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I will not be contradicted, Sir Maurice, you know it well enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I find it ſo, my Honey-ſuckle, but if you love me, let me hear what's her Fault; has ſhe by chance broken ſome of your fine China, I can buy more for you.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What a pitiful fancy is there, as if ſo trivial a thing could diſcompoſe my morals.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Then 'tis ſomething of great moment I ſee, has ſhe ſtolen ſome of your Plate?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: That were but a Trifle.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Mrs. Lucy, have you played the Thief, and pawned her Jewels?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: A great deal worſe ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Worſe ſtill, ſay you? Then ſhe has deſiled my Houſe, it muſt be ſo; Oh the Baggage!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: All this were nothing in compariſon of that horrid, ſcandalous, and exorbitant Offence ſhe is guilty of; hear it, Sir Maurice, ſince you have ſuch a mind to it, and excuſe her if you can with an Impudence beyond Example, and a ſhew of Ignorance that cannot be parallell'd in Hiſtory; ſhe had juſt now the ill manners to ſay in my hearing, That Cowley, the wretched Cowley, was as good a Poet, as the incomparable Sir Maggott Jingle.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: And is this all? Heaven be thanked; I thought ſhe had at leaſt ſet my Houſe on fire, or raviſh'd my Butler.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What's this mighty Wonder now? Is a Crime of this Nature a ſlight matter think you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With ſubmiſſion to the Wits, Madam, I do not conceive ſuch a Fault as this is puniſhable by the Laws of England; beſides, I never knew before, that my Maid was hired to admire Sir Maggot Jingle.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: How now, little Muſhroom? Are you one of her Advocates too? I ſhall indeed mind your pretty Reaſons.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: You'l want your faithful Conſident, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope there will be no need of a Conſident ſoon.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I underſtand your meaning, pretty Miſs, but your Buſineſs is done. I can aſſure you—Sir Maurice, I expect Sir Timothy here this Evening to ſeal the Writings, be you in the way—[To Mariana.] And you that have hitherto controul'd my Will, ſhew your ſelf Refractory now if you dare.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Father's Commands ſhall ever be a ſupream Law to me.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Then you are to learn, Mrs. Lackwit, that it muſt be my Husband's will, ſince it is my Pleaſure: Hold your impertinent Tongue I ſay, I am weary of your Nonſence—Sir Maurice, I'll in and give Orders for the Wedding, as I ſhall think ſit in my Wiſdom—[To Lovewit.] You Daughter, ſend immediately to Mr. Engroſs not to fail at the Hour appointed.

sp.speaker: Lovew
sp.p: I am ſorry, Siſter, Fortune proves ſo croſs to your Wiſhes; this World is full of Diſappointments.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.stage: [To Clerimont, coming from the corner where he ſtood liſtening.]
sp.p: Now you ſee it very plain, I hope, that ſhe is a Witch, my Heart trembled every Word ſhe ſpoke. What do you think on't? Tell me freely, is ſhe not an Enchantreſs? A pox of a Philoſopher for a Wiſe, who the Devil would marry Wit.

sp.speaker: Cler
sp.p: 'Tis more her Noiſe than her Wit keeps you in awe, Sir; raiſe but your Voice louder than hers when ſhe offers to ſpeak, and you'l ſilence her, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! on my Knees let me intreat you, do not abandon me to her unreaſonable Humour, make uſe of your Power, you may do it, 'tis nothing but Goodneſs, too much Goodneſs in your makes her thus haughty and imperious.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I vow, Sir, all the Neighbourhood cries ſhame upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I am as deſirous to have her Will oppoſed in this as any of you can be; but what can I do? How ſhall I deal with a Devil, that can at her pleaſure ſend a Legion of Evil Spirits to haunt and tear me a-pieces.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: With all her Spells, and Magick Art, Sir; take my word, your Lady can't raiſe but one Evil Spirit, and that's her own; but if you dare to put on a good Reſolution, and follow my Directions, we'll conquer that Evil Spirit, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Once more, good Sir, try what you can do, the Happineſs of your own Child depends upon it—Take pity of my Love.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Come, Sir, pluck up a Courage, ſtand upon your Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur
sp.p: Well—If you'l ſecond me, I'll in, and let her know who is her Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Well ſaid.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Tell her that none ought to rule in my Family but I.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Vigorouſly ſpoken.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Declare to her that you muſt be my Son in Law, and no body elſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Kindly and Bravely reſolved.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: And that if ſhe offers to contradict me, I'll ſhut her up.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: In Bedlam, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Come then, follow me all, and be ſure to ſtand by me.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Don't you fear it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: LOok you Roger, 50 l. is the Sum, and the task but eaſie, for the Man is both a Fool and a Coward.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Honeſt Jack, Let me alone with him; You know I'd hang my Own Father for half the Money, but where's the Woman?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Oh! Leave that part to me; I'll produce her in good time:—But here comes the Property, put on your Bloody Looks.
sp.stage: [Trap ſeeing his Maſter coming, alters the Tone of his Voice.]
sp.p: I tell you Sir, My Maſter is a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: A Man of Courage, Sir.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: All the better Sir; all the better.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: That has learnt to fence a whole Week; and ſhewn his Valour againſt the boldeſt Prentices in Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.stage: [Draws and thruſt at random, making as if he did not ſee Witleſs, who ſneaks behind Trap.]
sp.p: His Valour! Blood and Thunder! Let me ſee him. Ounds would I had him here.—There at his Heart,—There under the Second Rib;—Curſe on the ill luck, I han't kill'd a Man theſe three Days, and my Arm grows ſtiff for want of Exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Pray Sir, Good Sir, be not ſo furious if you can help it; My Maſter is a Gentleman underſtands Reaſon as well as any body; He'll give you all the Satisfaction you can deſire, I'm ſure; but pray put up Sir, put up, let me intreat you.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Well, Sir, Let's hear what is it you have to ſay?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I ſay, Sir, That this Gentleman here is my Maſter, and can give you the beſt Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Humh, Sir, are you the Man they call Mr. Witleſs?

sp.speaker: Witleſs.
sp.p: At your Service, good Sir, Honourable Sir.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Service! Blood and Thunder! 'Tis Juſtice I'll have, and no Service.

sp.speaker: Trap:
sp.p: Pray, Sir, Moderate your Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p:
Impertinent Varlet! hold thy peace, I charge you—
[To Witleſs.] To be plain Sir, this is my buſineſs with you; You have diſhonoured my Family, and I muſt have your Blood for it.

sp.speaker: Witleſs.
sp.p: I Sir! I proteſt I do not know you! I beg your pardon!—Alas, alas, Jack!

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Not know me, Blood and Thunder! perhaps ſo; but you know a Relation of mine, and with a Pox to you, you have known her to good purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Witleſs.
sp.p: Trap, Dear Trap, what's this? Can you gueſs what it is the Gentleman means?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not I, by Jericho; I am thinking all this while, what can be the meaning of all this ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Blood and Thunder! What muſt you ſtand there asking one another Queſtions; I tell you Sir, there are two ways and no more, either you muſt Marry my Cozen, you have after a moſt felonious manner impregnated, or elſe give me leave to cut your Throat preſently.

sp.speaker: Witleſs.
sp.p: O Sweet Sir, Gracious Sir, look upon me; I am not the Man you take me for.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Blood and Thunder! don't you think I'll be put off with a Story; I'll have every drop of thy Blood before I'll ſuffer mine to be ſtained: Here is a Paper you muſt Sign, or by Lucifer the next word you ſpeak, for a denial, I'll make the whole Firmament ſhine through your Liver.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But kind honey Sir, is there no way to accommodate—

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: What more Queſtions, you Pragmatical Dog, I'll order you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I mean no harm to you, Good Sir, but methinks—

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Impudent Sycophant, I'll nail thy prating Tongue to the Wall.

sp.speaker: Wittl.
sp.p: Good ſweet obliging Sir, may I ſpeak two words with my Man.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Be ſhort, Rot you, be ſhort.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Look you Jack, this ſcurvy Paper is nothing leſs than a promiſe of Marriage in Blank; for ought I know I may be Married one of theſe days to ſome filthy Sucbubus; He threatens to kill me if I don't Sign it; What muſt I do Jack, ſpeak, what muſt I do?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Do? That's a pretty Queſtion indeed; Rather dye a thouſand times and more, than conſent to ſuch Infamy; This is ſome Impudent trick I warrant it, the huſſing Raſcal has ſome Strumpet or other whom he has a mind to put off; Fight it out for ſhame— [Draws] I'll ſtand by you Sir.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.stage: [Draws, gets behind Trap and thruſts over his Shoulder.]
sp.p: Then Trap be ſtout; Come, you Blood and Thunder, here is my Anſwer for you.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Are you for the ſport then? have at you.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Puſh on brave Jack, puſh on.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Don't you fear Sir, ſpare him not—At his Heart directly if you can.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: You Pandar, ſtand off, or by the Bloody Bones of Dagon, this Steel ſhall make it ſelf a paſſage to his Heart through yours.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I Scorn your Words Sir, I'll dye upon the ſpot, rather than forſake my good Maſter; Thruſt on Sir, thruſt on, we'll Swindge him I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p:
Then Villain, take this— [Trap falls as if he were Wounded.
[To Witleſs.] Now for you Sir—

sp.speaker: Witleſs.
sp.p: Oh Sir! Valiant Sir, put up I beſeech you, I'll do any thing, I'll ſign any Paper, I'll Marry any body.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: I am very glad, Sir, to ſee you come to reaſon, for I have a great Eſteem for you, and 'twould have gone againſt my Heart, I vow, to kill a Gentleman who is to be my near Relation; here is the Paper, Sir, be pleaſed to ſet your hand to it, I love to be Civil.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Ay Sir; But if the Lady—

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Blood and Thunder! What more reaſoning yet.—

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh! No Sir, give me, give me— [Witleſs ſigns the Paper, and gives it to to Huff. There Sir—Alas, alas!—

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Now dear Cozen Witleſs, your moſt humble Servant; I eſteem my ſelf very happy in the honour of your Alliance.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Pox of his Honour,—By the Univerſity I'm in a fine Pickle, bound to Marry a VVitch for ought I can tell; and my Honeſt, my Faithful, my Fighting Trap murdered.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, is the Man gone?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh Fortune! Trap alive?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Ay Alive, and Unhurt, I hope.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: How! Unhurt, Jack; Did not I ſee you fall Dead upon the place?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: No, on my word, Sir, 'twas only a certain Giddineſs takes me at the ſight of a Naked Sword; 'tis an infirmity I had from my Youth.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Pray feel Jack if I am wounded; I may be Killed for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Nay you are in the right, for in the heat of Fighting 'tis ſeldom wounds are felt, can you VVhiſtle, let's hear.— [VVitleſs whiſtles in a ridiculous manner. That's well. Now let me ſee you Jump three times for the three Kingdoms.
Oh rare! I warrant you Living, and as ſound as a Roach; but pray now, what have you done about the Paper, the Curſed Paper.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Oh! The Villain made me ſet my Hand to it; I thought, Jack, 'twas better doing ſo, than be butchered by that Turk, and Infidel; His very Looks are enough to fright one out of Life; I vow as he ſtood thruſting at us, methought I ſaw Death and Maſſacre peeping out of the Corners of his Eyes; but I'll be even with him, I warrant him, for before Sir Timothy can hear of this, I'll to my Uncle in the Temple, and Hang the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Pray while his hand is in, let him diſpatch the Lady in Blank too, for if the Jade be once hanged, no Law in England can oblige you to marry her.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: VVell conſidered Faith; follow me Jack, and let's loſe no time.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: By no means Sir.

lg.l: Hanging will fail, I know, but I decree,
The Marriage-Knot ſhall more ſucceſsfull be;
And of theſe two the Deſtinies have told,
No matter which, ſo either of 'em hold.

div.head: Sir Maurice's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: BUt, Sir, a Coquet, a French Coquet, the word frights me; She'll have too much mettle for me: I ſhall be a Cuckold by the Univerſity I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I have known your Miſtreſs from a Child, Tim, and I am ſatisfied with my Choice; take this from me, Young Man, there is more Innocency in that brisk, pleaſant, and free humour of hers, than in the ſullen, rigid, and ſevere temper of many of her Sex, who thinking their Character ſecures 'em even from the Suſpicion of Vice, Blind and deceive the VVorld with a falſe appearance of Virtue, only to play their Under-game the more ſecurely.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: But, Sir, is there no certain compaſs for a Man to ſteer by upon the ſtormy Sea of Matrimony, without ſplitting againſt the Rock of Cuckoldom?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: There is no certain rule for it, Tim; however, let me give you this advice, Love your Wiſe heartily and ſincerely, be kind and faithful to her, and do not ſtarve her Longings; This is the beſt rule I know to keep her honeſt.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: 'Dslife! muſt a Husband then be bound to his good behaviour?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes certainly; for 'tis the moſt Unaccountable thing in the VVorld for a Man to complain that his VVife is not Virtuous, to whom he gives the worſt Example for Vice; Her diſloyalty cannot be juſtified that's true; but ſtill his anger is Unreaſonable. Look to your ſelf Tim when you come to be Married, for on my conſcience 'tis a dangerous thing to provoke a VViſe, who has always a revenge at hand.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: But, Sir, I may be kind to my VVife, and yet a Cuckold, what then?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh! In that caſe Boy, you muſt, like a VViſe Alderman, put your Hands into your Pockets and VVhiſtle.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Zookers! and is this all?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No Tim, there is ſtill this comfort left you, that the Horners of the Town make ſome Conſcience of their way, and are not quite ſo bad as Thieves and Robbers, who plunder and go away with all; No, the Gentlemen are mannerly, I muſt ſay that for 'em, for if they by chance break in, they take but juſt as much as will ſerve their turn, and always leave enough for a Man.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Mercy, Sir! commend me to good breeding; but ſtill my Honour Sir, my Honour: can your Mannerly Gentlemen take it away by bits and halves too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Honour Boy is but the Vulgar Error of Jealouſie, or the Bugbear of a Sick fancy; make no noiſe Tim and all may be well, for to my knowledge many a Man go for Cuckolds in the VVorld, who are not really ſo, and many are deeply ſo, who have not the reputation of it.—But here come the Ladies.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Meanwel, Catchat, Lovewit, and Engroſs, with VVritings.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Come Mr. Engroſs, you muſt change your rude and barbarous Style, and put theſe Articles of Marriage into more rhetorical Language; try if you can Houriſh them a little with a few paſſages out of Partheniſſa, Grand Cyrus, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: Our ſtyle, Madam, is like the Laws of the Medes and Serpents unalterable.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Your Cuſtom is a ſtrange Tyrant ſure, methinks you might at leaſt be ſo Gentile, as to date after the Roman manner, by Ides and Calends.

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: This is a contract between Engliſh Parties, and no Romans, Madam, You confound me.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: But for all you Mr. Engroſs, when I Marry, which I know will be ſoon now, I'll have all my VVritings drawn in Hieroglyphicks, and ſome Egyptian Prieſt, or Brachman of India to perform the Office.

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: Faith, Lady, thoſe Gentlemen live a great way off, and if you ſtay to Marry, till their arrival, your Virginity will deſerve a place in the Oxford Nackatory, among the pieces of Antiquity.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Maurice, Clerimont, and Mariana.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Remember, Sir, that your Wife is but a Woman, a meer Woman, and no Devil, no Enchantreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I'll order her, I warrant you, do but obſerve me.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Conſider, Dear Sir, I'm undone if ſhe prevails.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Don't you fear it, Child.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I cannot but admire at my Siſter's fancy; that ſhe ſhould bring in Clerimont, to be a Witneſs of his Rivals Triumph.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: You are miſtaken ſtill in Clerimont, Niece, he is carrying on another Intrigue than People imagine; I ſay little, but the thing will ſoon come out.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Are you ready Mr. Engroſs?

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: I want only the Names of the Parties; which is the Bride pray?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Here Sir, my Daughter-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Very well; her Name is Mariana, Sir.

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: Now for the Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Here's the Gentleman, Sir, Mr. Timothy Witleſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: And I ſay here's the Gentleman, Sir, Mr. Charles Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: Hey day! Two Husbands to one Wife, that's more than the Law allows, though perhaps no more than a Woman could very well diſpenſe withal.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: VVhy do you regard what other people ſay, Mr. Engroſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Did I not name Clerimont to you? what makes you ſtare?

sp.speaker: Engroſs.
sp.p: Uddsbudds! agree among your ſelves if you will, I'll go no further elſe.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: VVhat a Pox, my Dancing Maſter my Rival; Old Sir Maurice ſure, has a mind to make himſelf merry with him.—
sp.stage: Enter Trap, who takes Sir Timothy aſide.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: There's a Lady and a Gentleman below, Sir, have earneſt buſineſs with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Surely thou art mad, couldſt not thou tell 'em I was abroad.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Oh Sir! You never ſaw ſuch a Man in your Life, 'm ſure; I told him a thouſand times at leaſt, that you were here about buſineſs of great Importance; but he very unmannerly clap'd a Piſtol to my Breaſt, and Swore I was a dead Man, if I did not bring him to you immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: VVhat can this mighty buſineſs be?—With Sir Maurice's leave bring 'em in.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Come make an end, Mr. Engroſs, do as I bid you, for I have paſt my word, and I won't be an Aſs.
sp.stage: [Sir Timothy walks about the Door Huff and the Lady are to come in at.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: And ſo have I, Sir Maurice, and I won't be a Gooſe, but ſince there is no remedy, and my will I muſt have in ſpite of your Teeth, my Daughter here ſhall diſengage your word, the Gentleman, if he knows how to value VVit, will thank me ſure for this piece of Condeſcenſion.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Madam, may be a Miracle of VVit and Beauty, but ſtill I cannot but glory in owning to you, that I had rather dye a thouſand times than renounce my Love.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: They might have propoſed one to him, I know, would have been more acceptable.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: There was no need for you, Sir, to put your ſelf to the Expence of ſo fiery a proteſtation; I am not in ſo deſperate a condition yet, as to rob my Siſter of her few Admirers.
sp.stage: [Enter Huff and Lucy diſguiſed like a great belly'd Woman, Sir Tim. and Huff ſeem to argue very hotly at the Entrance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I ſhall never deſire, Madam, to put you to the tryal.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.stage: [Breaks from Sir Timothy, and comes towards the Company.]
sp.p: An Impoſtor! Blood and Thunder! I an Impoſtor! we ſhall try that, by Lucifer, we ſhall.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what's the matter? why in ſuch a paſſion?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Sir I beg your pardon, I beg your pardon; You look like a Gentleman, and though a Stranger to me I'll not ſcruple to make you a Judge between Sir Timothy, and this diſconſolate Lady: Let me but compoſe my ſelf a little, for his rudeneſs has ſtrangely diſordered me.
sp.stage: [While Huff is ſpeaking, Lucy falls a hugging and careſſing VVitleſs.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: O ſweet Honey! Cream of my Joys, have I found thee at laſt, I muſt Hugg thee; I muſt Buſs thee till my Lips ach.

sp.speaker: VVitl.
sp.p: Away, Satan, away; I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: O dear pretty ſmiling Rogue, how I Love thee! How Charmingly thou lookeſt; I vow thou wert unkind not to write to me, I muſt Kiſs thee for that too.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: By the Univerſity, the Women of this Town are as hot as Hell-Fire.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: I ſhall not trouble you, Sir, with a long ſtory; the Gentlewoman you ſee here is a near Relation of mine, who lived in Cambridge; She always had the reputation of as Modeſt and Virtuous a Lady as ever that Town bred, but her Eyes having the fatal Luck to boyl Mr. Witleſs's Blood into a Ferment, the young Gentleman would never be ſatisfied without a full Enjoyment of her Unfortunate body: She held out a great while, the poor Creature, but the Devil being powerful, and Female Fleſh Frail and Willing, ſhe was forced to Capitulate, and ſurrender the Fort of her Honour upon Articles; to be ſhort Sir, he gave her a promiſe of Marriage: Now hearing he was to be married to another, I made bold to intrude my ſelf, the buſineſs being of ſuch conſequence, as will I hope Apologize for the freedom.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I aſſure you Sir, 'tis an Impudent Lie, the fellow has told, examine into the buſineſs a little, and you ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oddſlicks! There was no need, Sir, of Apologie for your coming; you are moſt Welcome I promiſe you, make the moſt you can of your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Sir, may I ſpeak two words with you?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim
sp.p: You talk of a Promiſe of Marriage under my Son's hand, where is that Promiſe, pray, where is it?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Not far Sir,— [To Lucy.] Come, Cozen, produce your Title to Mr. Witleſs his Body.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
I have two Sir,—
[Pulls a Paper which ſhe gives to Sir Tim.] There is one of 'em,—The other is forth coming.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Tim. is this your hand? Look?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſo far I own.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: 'Sdlife! What will come of this pretty Story, there would be a wonder now, Ladies, ſhould a Scholar prove a Fornicator like other Men.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh the filthy Monſter! Is this your Cambridge breeding with a Pox?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I proteſt Sir, I am innocent, I never laid with a Woman in my life— Every time Witleſs goes about to Vindicate himſelf, Huff lays his Hand upon his Sword, which makes him to recant. but twice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: But twice with a Rope to you! what muſt you be a thouſand times about it?

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I Swear by both the Proctors of the Univerſity, I never attempted any thing upon the Sex—without their conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Now Lady, ſurely here is a Lawful Impediment with a Vengeance, why Mr. Witleſs ſhould not be joyned in Matrimony to my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'll Examine the Woman— [To Lucy.] Pray Miſtreſs, where did you firſt know my Son?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your Son, Sir, Knew me firſt at Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Did he Viſit you often Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Not often; but when he did, 'twas to ſome purpoſe, I aſſure you, the laſt time he carried me to Trumpington, there he Feaſted me, the good Man, I never ſaw him ſo wanton in my Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Trumpington! Oh the Damn'd Town! It lies upon the Road to Hell; I loſt my Maidenhead there before I knew I had one—But pray how far are you gone Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: My reckoning, Sir, as one may ſay, is from Sturbitch-Fair, we had a merry meeting there, I aſſure you, I ſhall remember it as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis too true! I'll ask no more queſtions; I remember now I ſent him his Quarter about that time, it muſt be ſo; Oh the Villain!

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Now Witty Females; what have you to ſay to this? You may bragg of your Scholars indeed.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Brother, this failure of the Fleſh is a Natural propenſity, againſt which our Philoſophy preſcribes no Rules.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Give me leave, Sir, but to ſpeak now in my defence; and I'll warrant you I'll make it as plain as any thing— [Huff laying his hand on his Sword.] that I have nothing to ſay againſt what the Gentleman ſpoke before.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Hold thy peace then Silly Puppy—
[To Trap aſide.] Look you honeſt Trap, I have given thee Warning, that's true, but thou art a Civil Fellow; I'll keep thee, if thou can'ſt do me a piece of Service.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Oh Sir! Do you queſtion my Zeal? You wrong me I vow, were I to be diſmiſſed next Minute, I would part with you like a Chriſtian; pray what's the buſineſs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: You ſee, Trap, this unlucky Wench is like to ſpoil my Son's match, I would have you take the man to your ſelf, and try what you can do with him. If a Preſent of 500 Guinea's will ſatisfie him, I'll give it freely; in the mean while, I'll make Sir Maurice believe 'twas only a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Do you but look well to your part, Sir, and truſt me with mine, and I'll warrant you, things will go ſwimmingly on our ſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: [To Sir Maur.] All this Story, Sir Maurice, proves at laſt nothing but a miſtake; the man took my Son for one Jeremy Witleſs of Briſtol, now Liſted in Flanders.
sp.stage: [Trap takes Huff aſide, they make as if they were arguing together.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I thought indeed, a man of Greek and Latin was above thoſe Infirmities.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Blood and Thunder, 500 Guinea's! I'll hang the whole Generation of 'em before I take 6000 l. What, for pitiful 500 l. ſell the Honour of my Family!
sp.stage: [Walks backward and forward between Trap and the Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, what's the matter now with the Gentleman? He makes a noiſe, and talks, I think, of 6000 l.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: The poor man is mad I fancy, that he has miſs'd his Prey; I ſuppoſe he ſays, he'd give 6000 l. to find him out.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: [Breaking off from Trap.] Blood and Thunder, let me go; I'll cut the Throat of Father and Son, or I'll have better ſatisfaction before I part.
sp.stage: Enter Meanwell, affecting a great ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Brother, I muſt make of this Day of Joy the moſt melancholy Day of your Life, by imparting to you the ſaddeſt News you could expect.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! Brother, what is it?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Our Hamburgh Ship has brought this diſmal Account, that Mynheer Van Punk is broke, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Alas! alas! I am undone, undone for ever, 20000 l. at a clap, I ſhall not be able to ſhew my Head.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh the unſeaſonable Misfortune!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Why ſo concern'd, Sir Maurice? What, now your weak and puny Soul muſt fret, and be diſturbed at this! Thanks to Philoſophy, mine is firm and unſhaken.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Fortune is ſafe ſtill; what Love could not do, Intereſt may—I'll not deſpair.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oddſzookers! the Caſe is altered: Hark you, Tim, I have always obſerved, that a man never thrives in the World that has wrong'd a modeſt Woman; therefore in point of Intereſt, as well as Conſcience, you muſt marry this Lady, and as a Pennance for your not Renouncing the Fleſh, Woman, and the Devil, ſwallow the bitter Cup of Matrimonial Twiſt.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I marry that Woman! Sir, I beg your Pardon, I ſhould be a Cornuto, and you know 'tis the only thing I hate.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good Boy, a man makes himſelf ridiculous in the World, that affects Singularity in any thing; you'l be Cuckolded a little before your time, that's true, but tis the faſhion now, therefore no Soul living will take notice of it.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Is it ſo upon your word, Sir? Or do you jeſt?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, Tim, upon my honeſt word 'tis e'en ſo—Cuckoldom is a raging Grievance of the Nation for all my mincing the matter. Juſt now, believe me, as many men as you ſee walking in the Streets, are as many Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: How ſo, pray? They are not all married ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: There is all the difference, Boy; with thoſe that are married their buſineſs is done, with thoſe that are not, their buſineſs is now doing: It was ſo with you, and juſt ſo 'twill be with 'em, comfort your ſelf with that.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I am as glad as any thing 'tis ſo, I proteſt I am, for to tell you the truth, the thing diſturbed me a little; but ſince you ſay 'tis the Mode, I ſcorn to be ſingular.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Beſides, Tim, Mrs. Meanwell has now loſt her Fortune, and Beggar for Beggar, 'tis much better for us you marry this good Lady here, for by this means we avoid a chargeable Suit, the man was talking of no leſs than 6000 l. Damages; hang him, 6000 l. would undo us—

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: By the Univerſity, I do not think there is one thouſand Pounds difference between an Honeſt VVoman, and a Common one.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Oh the Brute! what pity 't had been a VVoman of Virtue had fallen to the Lott of ſuch a Fool, who does not underſtand the Value of ſo great a Treaſure.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: By the tip of Plato's Ear, I am of the opinion of that famous Poet Tacitus, who ſays, He had rather be Cuckolded by a pretty coakſing loving VVife, than eſcape the Diſhonour, either through the Uglineſs, or the ſurly Virtue of one peeviſhly Honeſt.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, I rejoyce to ſee things run thus in a right Channel, and to make my Joy compleat, I have but one Favour more to beg of you, viz. That Mr. Witleſs, and my dear Relation here, may be joyned inſtantly, for I am commanded with my Regiment for Flanders to morrow early, and I ſhould not croſs the Sea with a quiet Mind, ſhould I leave this piece of Work unfiniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir, but where ſhall we find an Executioner?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: I have a Levitical Conjurer below, who, with Sir Maurice's leave, will give us a touch of his Black Art.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: My Houſe, Sir, is at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What ſay you to it, Tim? Come hang Conſideration, the ſhorteſt Follies are beſt.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Come then, Pig in a Poke, away to the Conjurer, thou art not the firſt has carried a great Belly to the Parſon.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Sir Timothy, Witleſs, Huff, and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Clerimont, I promiſed my ſelf a great deal of Happineſs in the Honour of your Alliance; but ſince my Hopes are defeated, and I cannot, in the Circumſtances I am in at preſent, offer poor Mariana to you for a Wife; I muſt thank you for your Civilities to her, and wiſh you ſomewhere elſe a Fortune anſwerable to your Merit.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You offend me, Sir Maurice, with this Diſcourſe: As it was not for her Fortune I courted your fair Daughter, ſo this Loſs ſhall make no change in me; I love her better than ever I did, all I have in the World is hers, and conſequently at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Then farewel to my Hopes there, I am put to my laſt Prayers indeed, but rather than fail I'll make ſure of Sir Maggot Jingle, his Wit ſhall be my Excuſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, Clerimont, you are too Generous, and whatever Violence I do to my Inclination in pronouncing the Words, we muſt part, Fortune has croſs'd my Wiſhes, and placed my Heart beneath you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Oh killing words! Cruel Mariana! do you, do you oppoſe my Happineſs? Who could have ſuſpected it? My Heart was not prepared for ſo ſevere a ſtroke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis not, Clerimont, becauſe I hate you, or love you leſs; Heaven, that ſees into my Breaſt, knows how pure and ſincere is my Love for you, but I am ſenſible that your Eſtate requires a preſent Fortune to make you eaſie: I wiſhed to be yours, when I had reaſon to hope my Father's Kindneſs would have made us live happily in the World; but ſince Heaven has decreed otherwiſe, I muſt not be ſo ungrateful to your Love, as to deſire to be an Obſtacle to your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: If you have not a mind, Divine Mariana, to ſee a ſad Lover expire at your Feet, forbear talking, any more of Fortune, the whole World without you cannot make me happy, and with you I am richer than the greateſt Monarch upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fortune, which has robb'd me of all my Hopes, could not rob you of my Heart, it is yours, Clerimont, in ſpite of her, and if I owed it all before to your Love, what can I give now to your Generoſity?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Your ſelf, Madam, and in you all that this World can gratifie my Ambition withal.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, Witleſs, Huff, and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: I fancy the Sin is worth the owning, the Creature feels as a ſound piece of Mortality; 'tis but ſuppoſing the firſt night we lay together, that we have been married 4 or 5 months, and all is well.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good Tim, my mind is now at eaſe, to ſee you a man like my ſelf, and by this Heroick Act of yours do I know you to be of the true Blood of the Witleſſes, who for theſe five Generations have outbraved Cuckoldom: Come, thou art a good Boy, and haſt the true notion of the thing.

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Nay, I think I am as good a man as I was before; my Leg is as ſtreight now as it was in the morning, and I find not the leaſt alteration in my Health; why ſhould I be melancholy? I ſee no cauſe, not I.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: This is the Wheel of Fortune, Mr. Witleſs; when People boaſt of Favours they never enjoy'd, they come often to father Children they never got: [Throws off her Diſguiſe.] But ſee, you have better Luck than you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! what have we here?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Honeſt Lucy, at your ſervice, as pure a Virgin as ever was born—for all your bragging, Mr. Witleſs—

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: Trap, you Trap, by the Univerſity thy pretty Siſter—Oddſzooks! 'tis well 'tis no worſe.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I had a pretty Match for her in my Eye, but ſince Deſtiny throws her upon you, I'll not contend with your Stars; take her and wear her, ſhe is yours, I hope you'l uſe her civilly.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Surely Sir Timothy will not ſuffer his witty Son to be thus proſtituted to an illiterate Abigail—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not I, by Hell! This is an impudent Cheat, a Trick of that Raſcal there, I ſmoak it out, but I'll ſee 'em all hang'd; I'll to Juſtice immediately: Juſtice! Juſtice!

sp.speaker: Witl.
sp.p: You may hang the reſt if you pleaſe, Father, but I'll take care to hang this little Rogue my ſelf: Come, dear Lucy, thou melting Sugar-loaf of Pleaſure, thou art a good Girl, by the Univerſity I always loved thee; give me thy Hand, I'll ſay it once more, thou art my Wife: Let Sir Timothy fume, my Mother's Land is 500 l. per Annum, and that's enough for us: Hocus Pocus, thou art a Maid to day, I'll make thee a Woman to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So much Juſtice you owe me, I'm ſure for your vain boaſting; but look to your ſelf now, I'll be even with you, I warrant you, and turn your Fictions into Real Hiſtory with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Now, Lady Grumble, are you convinced that Mr. Witleſs is not to have my Daughter? Shall we at laſt have the favour of your Conſent for this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: No, Sir Maurice, not as long as I breath; what, do you think I'll admit into my Family a Deſpiſer of Wit, one who knows well enough I'm an Author, and never had the manners to ask me to read any of my Works to him?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I am not, Madam, ſuch an Enemy to Wit as your Ladyſhip makes me, I love it but as a Gentleman, without either Pride or Affectation; I could Entertain the Company with a ſmall Eſſay of my Poetry, a SONG I made yeſterday, if you could promiſe your ſelves patience enough to hear it.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Hear it? Ay, with all our Hearts; who is there to ſing it?

lg.l: LOve, thou art beſt of Human Joys,
Our chiefeſt Happineſs below,
All other Pleaſures are but Toys;
Muſick, without thee, is but Noiſe,
And Beauty but an empty Show.
Heav'n, who knew beſt what Man could move,
And raiſe his Thoughts above the Brute,
Said, Let him be, and let him love,
That muſt alone his Soul improve,
Howe'er Philoſophers diſpute.

sp.speaker: Wilt.
sp.p: I proteſt the man writes well enough for a Fidler.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh rare! I hope your Ladyſhip is ſatisfied now.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Maurice, I'm ſatisfied that that man muſt be your Son-in-Law; and my Reaſon for it is, becauſe he is a Ninny, and a Booby.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! what a Babel is here? Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Where are we, ſay you? In the worſt place in the World for Manners ſure; what for a man to be ſo hardy, ſo Effronté, and ſo deſtitute of Politeneſs and Compliſance, as to affront Philoſophy to my face, is a Crime never to be atoned for, however Philoſophers diſpute, quoth he: That's as much as to ſay, we are Fools; my Siſter, Daughter, and I, all Fools.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I never heard my Siſter draw a more natural Concluſion in my Life.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: But I'll revenge Philoſophy I'm reſolved; and to make an Example of this Unmannerly Compoſer of Songs, I'll inflict upon him the Curſe of a poor ſilly Portionleſs Wife. Sir Mauriee, whether you will or no, that ignorant Songſter there ſhall have your Daughter, his ſhallow Wit will fit her little Genius, as well as her Hamburgh Fortune his ſhatter'd Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Pleaſe your ſelf, Madam, with your mean Railleries, I am ſenſible of nothing but my preſent Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Did not I tell you, Mariana, we ſhould carry the day? I knew well enough I ſhould bring it to paſs. Now we are all pleaſed, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Only, poor Siſter Catchat, ſhe has reaſon to take it ill, that in ſo plentiful a diſtribution of Human Fleſh ſhe can catch nothing, but muſt at laſt take up with her Men in the Moon, or her Viſions and Chimera's.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Ay, Chimera's; let my Niece look to her ſelf, there reigns one ſtill in Clerimont's Heart will make her live uneaſie all her days, let me tell her that, and ſo Adieu.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Inſert this in the Articles, Mr. Engroſs; I charge you, that this illiterate Couple ſhall never come into my Houſe, I'll not be peſter'd with ſtupid Creatures, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Not into my Houſe? By my Lord Maylor I'll leave you, Lady Petulant, with your Jingles to make Almanacks and Ballads.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the World ſhall ſee how much I value Wit in ſpite of Fools; Sir Maggot Jingle ſhall be my Son-in-Law, and for the future none ſhall be admitted into my Houſe but Beaux Eſprits; therefore, Sir Maurice, think of another Habitation for your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You are Maſter of my Houſe, Sir, and ſhall Command in it more abſolutely than you did in your own.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: The Kindneſs, Sir, will be ſeaſonable.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Then ſince you are pleaſed ſo impertinently to Inſult, know, Siſter, to your confuſion, that the News from Hamburgh is falſe, that my Niece's Fortune is not loſt, but rather improved by a conſiderable Return. I put this trick upon you to try your Philoſophy, and let the World ſee to the bottom of Female Wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: Oh, dear Brother, you revive me! How happy am I, that I have ſtill a fortune to make a Return to Clerimont's Generoſity— [To Cler.] It is all yours, Sir; give me leave to make the reſt of my Life happy in your, and my Daughter's Company, and retire with you into Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This will compleat my Happineſs, Heaven be thank'd: I ſhall have all I could wiſh for in this World, my Father, and Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: And bleſſed be my Stars, ſay I, that Ignorance and Wit ſhall dwel no more together; farewel rude and unpoliſh'd Crowd: You witty Daughter of mine, follow me.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Brother, let this Day be Celebrated as a Day of Joy and Deliverance to your Family, from the Tyrannical and Arbitrary Power of a Proud, Scolding, Whimſical, Philoſophical Wife: You have now got a ſecond that will ſtand by you, I'm ſure. Let not therefore an impertinent Female Wit Uſurp again ſo unreaſonable an Empire over you.

sp.speaker: Sir Maur.
sp.p: I'll make the beſt of your Advice to be ſure; but, good Brother, whatever the Task may ſeem to one without Experience, take my word all married men find it a difficult one.

l.hi: Man firſt was deſtin'd for the Sov'reign Sway,
But haughty Woman, ſcorning to obey,
Call'd to her Beauty's Aid, the Serpent's Art,
Surpris'd his Reaſon, and Enſnar'd his Heart:
Since when we ſtruggle for our Right in vain,

div.l: Their Tongues and Eyes will ſtill the Rule maintain. &c.

lg.l: I Try'd to leave you, Gentlemen, in vain,
The reſt are gone, but I'm return'd again;
And that you're pleas'd, my Vanity diſcovers,
I'll ſet you all down in my Liſt of Lovers,
And think you ſo, whate'er Defence you make;
Nay more, I'll prove is for my Humour's ſake,
That none are Happy, but through ſome Miſtake.
The faireſt Nymph that thinks ſh'as gain'd a Heart,
And does her Favours, with her Smiles, impart,
Whilſt here the Spark practiſes all his Graces,
Ne'er thinks, alas! they're levell'd at new Faces,
Cheated on ſtill by his Perſidious Eyes,
She vainly fancies, 'tis for her he dies.
The Elder Ladies too, of paſt Renown,
Have their Miſtakes; Stale Fortunes of the Town
Think there's no Lord, but might ha' been their own.
And ſlighting Lovers of their Fancy born,
Starve for that Bleſſing they affect to Scorn;
At length Deſpis'd, turn Cenſurers, and Nice,
And boaſt of Virtue, 'cauſe unfit for Vice.
You, Riſing Suns, who ſee their dreadful Fate,
Take Warning, Marry e'er it be too late,
For Youth's the ſureſt Charm to Captivate.
Our Author too, for who ſo Vain as they,
Would needs believe that you Approve his Play;
E'en humour him for Once, and give him Cauſe,
Warm him but with the Fire of your Applauſe.
Then, If again his Muſe her Voice ſhall raiſe,
Yours be the Merit, yours be all the Praiſe;
You make the POET, he but makes the PLAYS.
